title-group.article-title: The success of artificial selection for collective composition hinges on initial and target values

institution-wrap.institution: Asia Pacific Center for Theoretical Physics
Centre for Life’s Origins and Evolution, Department of Genetics, Evolution and Environment, University College London

fn.p: Integrated Science Lab, Department of Physics, Umeå university, Umeå, Sweden

event.event-desc: This manuscript was published as a preprint.
This manuscript was published as a reviewed preprint.

abstract.p: Microbial collectives can perform functions beyond the capability of individual members. Enhancing collective functions through artificial selection is, however, challenging. Here, we explore the ‘rafting-a-waterfall’ metaphor where achieving a target population composition depends on both target and initial compositions. Specifically, collectives comprising fast-growing (F) and slow-growing (S) individuals were grown for ‘maturation’ time, and the collective with S-frequency closest to the target value is chosen to ‘reproduce’ via inoculating offspring collectives. During collective maturation, intra-collective selection acts like a waterfall, relentlessly driving the S-frequency to lower values, while during collective reproduction, inter-collective selection resembles a rafter striving to reach the target frequency. Using simulations and analytical calculations, we show that intermediate target S frequencies are the most challenging, akin to a target within the vertical drop of a waterfall, rather than above or below it. This arises because intra-collective selection is the strongest at intermediate S-frequencies, which can overpower inter-collective selection. While achieving a low target S frequencies is consistently feasible, attaining high target S-frequencies requires an initially high S-frequency — much like a raft that can descend but not ascend a waterfall. As Newborn size increases, the region of achievable target frequency is reduced until no frequency is achievable. In contrast, the number of collectives under selection plays a less critical role. In scenarios involving more than two populations, the evolutionary trajectory must navigate entirely away from the metaphorical ‘waterfall drop.’ Our findings illustrate that the strength of intra-collective evolution is frequency-dependent, with implications in experimental planning.

custom-meta.meta-value: Mathematical modeling uncovers how initial and target compositions limit microbial community selection, as inter-community selection clashes with intra-community selection like a rafter battling a waterfall.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Microbial collectives can carry out functions that arise from interactions among member species. These functions, such as waste degradation (Woo et al., 2020; Sun et al., 2022), probiotics (Bober et al., 2018), and vitamin production (Wang et al., 2016), can be useful for human health and biotechnology. To improve collective functions, one can perform artificial selection (directed evolution) on collectives (see Figure 1): Low-density ‘Newborn’ collectives are allowed to ‘mature’ during which cells proliferate and possibly mutate, and community function develops. ‘Adult’ collectives with high functions are then chosen to reproduce, each seeding multiple offspring Newborns. Artificial selection of collectives have been attempted both in experiments (Goodnight, 1990; Swenson et al., 2000b; Swenson et al., 2000a; Blouin et al., 2015; Panke-Buisse et al., 2015; Panke-Buisse et al., 2017; Jochum et al., 2019; Wright et al., 2019; Raynaud et al., 2019; Arora et al., 2020; Chang et al., 2020; Mueller et al., 2021; Jacquiod et al., 2022; Raynaud et al., 2022; Arias-Sánchez et al., 2024) and in simulations (Penn, 2003; Penn and Harvey, 2004; Williams and Lenton, 2007; Xie et al., 2019; Doulcier et al., 2020; Xie and Shou, 2021; Chang et al., 2021; Fraboul et al., 2023; Lalejini et al., 2022; Zaccaria et al., 2023; Vessman et al., 2023), often with unimpressive outcomes.

caption.title: Schematic for artificial selection on collectives.
caption.p: Each selection cycle begins with a total of g\begin{document}$g$\end{document} Newborn collectives, each with N0\begin{document}$N_{0}$\end{document} total cells of slow-growing S population (light gray dots) and fast-growing F population (dark gray dots). During maturation (over time τ\begin{document}$\tau$\end{document}), S and F cells divide at rates rS\begin{document}$r_{S}$\end{document} and rS+ω\begin{document}$r_{S}+\omega$\end{document} (ω>0\begin{document}$\omega \gt 0$\end{document}), respectively, and S mutates to F at rate μ\begin{document}$\mu$\end{document}. During inter-collective selection, the Adult collective with F frequency f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} closest to the target composition f^\begin{document}$\hat{f}$\end{document} is chosen to reproduce g\begin{document}$g$\end{document} Newborns for the next cycle. Newborns are sampled from the chosen Adult (yellow star) with N0\begin{document}$N_{0}$\end{document} cells per Newborn. The selection cycle is then repeated until the F frequency reaches a steady state, which may or may not be the target composition. To denote a variable x\begin{document}$x$\end{document} of i\begin{document}$i$\end{document}-th collective in cycle k\begin{document}$k$\end{document} at time t\begin{document}$t$\end{document} (0≤t≤τ\begin{document}$0\leq t\leq\tau$\end{document}), we use notation xk,t(i)\begin{document}$x_{k,t}^{(i)}$\end{document} where x∈{S,F,s, f}\begin{document}$x\in\{S, F, s,\ f\}$\end{document}. Note that time t=0\begin{document}$t=0$\end{document} is for Newborns and t=τ\begin{document}$t=\tau$\end{document} is for Adults.

sec.p: One of the major challenges in selecting collectives is to ensure the inheritance of a collective function (Xie et al., 2023; Thomas et al., 2024). Inheritance from a parent collective to offspring collectives can be compromised by changes in genotype and species compositions. During maturation of a collective, genotype compositions within each species can change due to intra-collective selection favoring fast-growing individuals (Figure 1, ‘intra-collective’ selection), while species compositions can change due to ecological interactions. Furthermore, during the reproduction of a collective, genotype and species compositions of offspring can vary stochastically from those of the parent (Figure 1, ‘genetic drift’).

Here, we consider the selection of collectives comprising two or three populations with different growth rates, and our goal is to achieve a target composition in the Adult collective. This is a common quest: whenever a collective function depends on both populations, the collective function is maximized, by definition, at an intermediate frequency (e.g. too little of either population will hamper function; Xie et al., 2019). Earlier work has demonstrated that nearly any target species composition can be achieved when selecting communities of two competing species with unequal growth rates (Doulcier et al., 2020; Rainey, 2023), so long as the shared resource is depleted during collective maturation (Doulcier et al., 2020). In this case, initially, both species evolved to grow faster, and the slower-growing species was preserved due to stochastic fluctuations in species composition during collective reproduction. Eventually, both species evolved to grow sufficiently fast to deplete the shared resource during collective maturation, and evolution in competition coefficients then acted to stabilize the species ratio to the target value (Doulcier et al., 2020). Regardless, earlier studies are often limited to numerical explorations, with prohibitive costs for a full characterization of the parameter space for such nested populations (population of collectives, and populations of variants within a collective).

We mathematically examine the selection of composition in collectives consisting of populations growing at different rates. We made simplifying assumptions so that we can analytically examine the evolutionary tipping point between intra-collective and inter-collective selection. We show that this tipping point creates a ‘waterfall’ effect which restricts not only which target compositions are achievable, but also the initial composition required to achieve the target. We also investigate how the range of achievable target composition is affected by the total population size in Newborns and the total number of collectives under selection. Finally, we show that the waterfall phenomenon extends to systems with more than 2 populations.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: To enable the derivation of an analytical expression, we have made the following simplifying assumptions. First, growth is always exponential, without complications such as resource limitation, ecological interactions between the two populations, or density-dependent growth. Thus, the exponential growth equation can be used. Second, we initially consider only two populations (genotypes or species): the fast-growing F population with size F\begin{document}$F$\end{document} and the slow-growing S population with size S\begin{document}$S$\end{document}. We do not consider a spectrum of mutants or species, since with more than two populations, an analytical solution becomes very difficult. Finally, the single top-functioning community is chosen to reproduce, which allows us to employ the simplest version of the extreme value theory (see section below for further justification).

Our goal is to select for collective composition in terms of F frequency f=F/(S+F)\begin{document}$f=F/(S+F)$\end{document}, or equivalently, S frequency s=1−f\begin{document}$s=1-f$\end{document}. More precisely, we want collectives such that after maturation time τ\begin{document}$\tau$\end{document}, f(τ)\begin{document}$f(\tau)$\end{document} is as close to the target value f^\begin{document}$\hat{f}$\end{document} as possible (Figure 1). Note that even if the target frequency has been achieved, since F frequency will always increase during maturation, inter-collective selection is required in each cycle to maintain the target frequency.

We will start with a complete model where S mutates to F at a nonzero mutation rate μ\begin{document}$\mu$\end{document}. We made this choice because it is more challenging to attain or maintain the target frequency when the abundance of fast-growing F is further increased via mutations. This scenario is encountered in biotechnology: an engineered pathway will slow down cell growth, and breaking the pathway (and thus faster growth) is much easier than the other way around. When the mutation rate is set to zero, the same model can be used to capture collectives of two species with different growth rates. We show that intermediate F frequencies or equivalently, intermediate S frequencies, are the hardest targets to achieve. We then show using simulations that similar conclusions hold when selecting for a target composition in collectives of three populations.

sec.title: Model structure
sec.p: A selection cycle (Figure 1; Table 1) starts with a total of g\begin{document}$g$\end{document} Newborn collectives. At the beginning of cycle k\begin{document}$k$\end{document} (t=0\begin{document}$t=0$\end{document}), each Newborn collective has a fixed total cell number N0=Sk,0(i)+Fk,0(i)\begin{document}$N_{0}=S_{k,0}^{(i)}+F_{k,0}^{(i)}$\end{document} where Sk,t(i)\begin{document}$S_{k,t}^{(i)}$\end{document} and Fk,t(i)\begin{document}$F_{k,t}^{(i)}$\end{document} denote the numbers of S and F cells in collective i\begin{document}$i$\end{document} (1≤i≤g\begin{document}$1\leq i\leq g $\end{document}) at time t\begin{document}$t$\end{document} (0≤t≤τ\begin{document}$0\leq t\leq\tau$\end{document}) of cycle k\begin{document}$k$\end{document}. The average F frequency among the g\begin{document}$g$\end{document} Newborn collectives in cycle k\begin{document}$k$\end{document} is f¯k,0\begin{document}$\overline{f}_{k,0}$\end{document}, such that the initial F cell number in each Newborn is drawn from the binomial distribution Binom(N0,f¯k,0)\begin{document}$\mathrm{Binom}(N_{0},\overline{f}_{k,0})$\end{document}.

tr.td: Total cell numbers in a collective, N=S+F\begin{document}$N=S+F$\end{document}
Frequency of S cells, s=S/(S+F)\begin{document}$s = S/(S + F)$\end{document}
F frequency of the selected collective in a cycle
Growth rate advantage of F over S
Mutation rate from S to F
Total number of cells in Newborn, or Newborn size
Target frequency in s\begin{document}$s$\end{document} or f\begin{document}$f$\end{document}.
Low and High thresholds of inaccessible f^\begin{document}$\hat{f}$\end{document}
Fold-growth of S cells over time τ\begin{document}$\tau$\end{document}, Rτ=erSτ\begin{document}$R_{\tau}=e^{r_{S}\tau}$\end{document}
Fold ratio change of F cells over S cells over time τ\begin{document}$\tau$\end{document}, Wτ=eωτ\begin{document}$W_{\tau}=e^{\omega\tau}$\end{document}

sec.p: Collectives are allowed to grow for time τ\begin{document}$\tau$\end{document} (‘Maturation’ in Figure 1). During maturation, S and F grow at rates rS\begin{document}$r_{S}$\end{document} and rS+ω\begin{document}$r_{S}+\omega$\end{document} (ω>0\begin{document}$\omega \gt 0$\end{document}), respectively. If maturation time τ\begin{document}$\tau$\end{document} is too small, a matured collective (‘Adult’) does not have enough cells to reproduce g\begin{document}$g$\end{document} Newborn collectives with N0\begin{document}$N_{0}$\end{document} cells. On the other hand, if maturation time τ\begin{document}$\tau$\end{document} is too long, fast-growing F will take over. Hence, we set the maturation time τ=ln⁡(g+1)/rS\begin{document}$\tau=\ln(g+1)/r_{S}$\end{document}, which guarantees sufficient cells to produce g\begin{document}$g$\end{document} Newborn collectives from a single Adult collective. At the end of a cycle, a single Adult with the highest function (with F frequency f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} closest to the target frequency f^\begin{document}$\hat{f}$\end{document}) is chosen to reproduce g\begin{document}$g$\end{document} Newborn collectives, each with N0\begin{document}$N_{0}$\end{document} cells (‘Selection’ and ’Reproduction’ in Figure 1). Note that even though S and F do not compete for nutrients, they compete for space: because the total number of cells transferred to the next cycle is fixed, an overabundance of one population will reduce the likelihood of the other being propagated.

Collective function is dictated by the Adult’s F frequency f\begin{document}$f$\end{document}. Among all Adult collectives, the selected Adult is the one whose F frequency is closest to the target value, f^\begin{document}$\hat{f}$\end{document}. In contrast with findings from an earlier study (Xie et al., 2019), choosing top 1 is more effective than the less stringent ‘choosing top 5%.’ In the earlier study, variation in the collective trait is partly due to nonheritable factors such as random fluctuations in Newborn biomass. In that context, a less stringent selection criterion proved more effective, as it helped retain collectives with favorable genotypes that might have exhibited suboptimal collective traits due to unfavorable non-heritable factors. However, since this study excludes non-heritable variations in collective traits, selecting the top 1 collective is more effective than selecting the top 5% (see Appendix 7—figure 1).

The selected Adult, with F frequency denoted as f∗\begin{document}$f^{*}$\end{document}, is then used to reproduce g\begin{document}$g$\end{document} offspring collectives, each with N0\begin{document}$N_{0}$\end{document} total cells. The number of F cells in a newborn follows a binomial distribution B(N0,f∗)\begin{document}$B(N_0,f^*)$\end{document}. By repeating the selection cycle, we aim to achieve and maintain the target composition f^\begin{document}$\hat{f}$\end{document}.

Overall, our model considers mutational stochasticity, as well as demographic stochasticity in terms of stochastic birth and stochastic sampling of a parent collective by offspring collectives. Other types of stochasticity, such as environmental stochasticity and measurement noise, are not considered and require future research.

sec.title: The success of collective selection is constrained by the target composition, and sometimes also by the initial composition
sec.p: Since intra-collective selection favors F, we expect that a higher target f^\begin{document}$\hat{f}$\end{document} (a lower target s^\begin{document}$\hat{s}$\end{document}) is easier to achieve. By ‘achieve,’ we mean that the absolute error d\begin{document}$d$\end{document} between the target frequency f^\begin{document}$\hat{f}$\end{document} and the selected frequency averaged among independent simulations ⟨f∗⟩\begin{document}$\langle f^{*}\rangle$\end{document} is smaller than 0.05 (i.e.d=|⟨f∗⟩−f^|≤0.05\begin{document}$d=|\langle f^{*}\rangle-\hat{f}|\leq 0.05$\end{document}).

We fixed N0,\begin{document}$N_{0},$\end{document} the total population size of a Newborn to 1000, and obtained selection dynamics for various initial and target F frequencies by implementing stochastic simulations (Appendix 1). If the target f^\begin{document}$\hat{f}$\end{document} is high (e.g. 0.9, Figure 2a magenta), selection is successful (computed absolute errors Appendix 1—figure 4): regardless of the initial frequency, f∗\begin{document}$f^{*}$\end{document} of the chosen collective eventually converges to the target f^\begin{document}$\hat f$\end{document} and stays around it. In contrast, without collective-level selection (e.g. choosing a random collective to reproduce), F frequency increases until F reaches fixation (Supplementary information Appendix 1—figure 3b).

caption.title: Initial and target compositions determine the success of artificial selection on collectives.
caption.p: (a–c) F frequency of the selected Adult collective (f∗\begin{document}$f^{*}$\end{document}) over cycles at different target f^\begin{document}$\hat{f}$\end{document} values (long dashed lines). f^\begin{document}$\hat{f}$\end{document} between fL\begin{document}$f^{L}$\end{document} and fH\begin{document}$f^{H}$\end{document} (orange dotted and solid line segments) is inaccessible where selection will fail. (a) A high target F frequency (e.g.f^=0.9>fH\begin{document}$\hat{f}=0.9 \gt f^{H}$\end{document}; magenta) can be achieved from any initial frequency (black dots). (b) An intermediate target frequency (e.g.fL<f^=0.5<fH\begin{document}$f^{L} \lt \hat{f}=0.5 \lt f^{H}$\end{document}; green) is never achievable, as all initial conditions converge to fH\begin{document}$f^{H}$\end{document}. (c) A low target frequency (e.g. f^=0.1<fL\begin{document}$\hat f=0.1\ltf^L$\end{document}; dark blue) is achievable, but only from initial frequencies below fL\begin{document}$f^{L}$\end{document}. For initial frequencies at fL\begin{document}$f^{L}$\end{document}, stochastic outcomes (gray curves) are observed: while some replicates reached the target frequency, others reached fH\begin{document}$f^{H}$\end{document}. For parameters, we used S growth rate rS=0.5\begin{document}$r_{S}=0.5$\end{document}, F growth advantage ω=0.03\begin{document}$\omega=0.03$\end{document}, mutation rate μ=0.0001\begin{document}$\mu=0.0001$\end{document}, maturation time τ≈4.8\begin{document}$\tau\approx 4.8$\end{document}, and N0=1000\begin{document}$N_{0}=1000$\end{document}. The number of collectives g=10\begin{document}$g=10$\end{document}. Each black line is averaged from independent 300 realizations. (d) Inter-collective selection opposes intra-collective selection. We plot probability density distributions of F frequency f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} during two consecutive cycles when selection is successful. Data correspond to cycles 31 and 32 from the second lowest initial point in c. Δf\begin{document}$\Delta f$\end{document} is the selection progress within a cycle (see Box 1). Black triangle: median. (e) Two accessible regions (gold). Either high f^\begin{document}$\hat{f}$\end{document} (f^>fH\begin{document}$\hat{f} \gt f^{H}$\end{document}; region 2) or low f^\begin{document}$\hat{f}$\end{document} starting from low initial f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} (f^<fL\begin{document}$\hat{f} \lt f^{L}$\end{document} and f¯1,0<fL\begin{document}$\overline{f}_{1,0} \lt f^{L}$\end{document}; region 1) can be achieved. We theoretically predict (by numerically integrating Equation 1) fH\begin{document}$f^{H}$\end{document} (orange solid line) and fL\begin{document}$f^{L}$\end{document} (orange dotted line), which agree with simulation results (gold regions). (f) Example trajectories from initial compositions (black dots) to the target compositions (dashed lines). The gold areas indicate the region of initial frequencies where the target frequency can be achieved. (g) The tension between intra-collective selection and inter-collective selection creates a ‘waterfall’ phenomenon. See the main text for details.

boxed-text.label: Box 1.

caption.title: Changes in the distribution of F frequency f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} after one cycle

boxed-text.p: We consider the case where fk∗\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*}$\end{document}, the F frequency of the selected Adult at cycle k\begin{document}$k$\end{document}, is above the target value (fk∗>f^\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*} \gt \hat{f}$\end{document}). This case is particularly challenging because intra-collective evolution favors fast-growing F and thus will further increase f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} away from the target. From fk∗\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*}$\end{document}, Newborns of cycle k+1\begin{document}$k+1$\end{document} will have f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} fluctuating around fk∗\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*}$\end{document}, and after they mature, the minimum f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} is selected (fk+1∗=min[fk+1,τ(1),fk+1,τ(2),⋯,fk+1,τ(g)]\begin{document}$f_{k+1}^{*}=\text{min}\left[f_{k+1,\tau}^{(1)},f_{k+1,\tau}^{(2)},\cdots,f_{k+ 1,\tau}^{(g)}\right]$\end{document}). If the selected composition at cycle k+1\begin{document}$k+1$\end{document} can be reduced compared to that of cycle k\begin{document}$k$\end{document} (i.e. fk+1∗<fk∗\begin{document}$f_{k+1}^{*} \lt f_{k}^{*}$\end{document}), the system can evolve to the lower target value.

To find fk∗\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*}$\end{document} values such that fk+1∗<fk∗\begin{document}$f_{k+1}^{*} \lt f_{k}^{*}$\end{document}, we used the median value of the conditional probability distribution Ψ\begin{document}$\Psi$\end{document} of fk+1∗\begin{document}$f_{k+1}^{*}$\end{document} given the selected fk∗\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*}$\end{document} at cycle k\begin{document}$k$\end{document} (mathematical details in Appendix 2). If the median value (Median[Ψ(fk+1∗|fk∗)]\begin{document}$\mathrm{Median}[\Psi(f_{k+1}^{*}|f_{k}^{*})]$\end{document}) is smaller than fk∗\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*}$\end{document}, then selection will likely be successful since the selected Adult in cycle k+1\begin{document}$k+1$\end{document} has more than 50% chance to have a reduced F frequency compared to cycle k\begin{document}$k$\end{document}.

There are two points where the median values are the same as fk∗\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*}$\end{document} (Figure 3a), which are assigned as lower-threshold (fL\begin{document}$f^{L}$\end{document}) and higher-threshold (fH\begin{document}$f^{H}$\end{document}).

Following the extreme value theory, the conditional probability density function Ψ(fk+1∗=f|fk∗)\begin{document}$\Psi(f_{k+1}^{*}=f \:|\:f_{k}^{*})$\end{document} is(1)Ψ(fk+1∗=f|fk∗)=gPfk+1,τ(f|fk∗)[1−∫0fdf′Pfk+1,τ(f′|fk∗)]g−1.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \Psi(f_{k+1}^{*}\!=\!f \,|\:f_{k}^{*})=gP_{f_{k+1,\tau}}(f\,|\:f_{k}^{*})\left[1-\int_{0}^{f}df'P_{f_{k+1,\tau}}(f'|\:f_{k}^{*})\right]^{g-1}.$$\end{document}

Equation 1 can be described as the product between two terms related to probability: (i) gPfk+1,τ(f|fk∗)\begin{document}$gP_{f_{k+1,\tau}}(f \:|\:f_{k}^{*})$\end{document} describes the probability density that any one of the g\begin{document}$g$\end{document} Adult collectives achieves f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} given fk∗\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*}$\end{document}, and (ii) [1−∫0fdf′Pfk+1,τ(f′|fk∗)]g−1\begin{document}$\left[1-\int_{0}^{f}df^{\prime}P_{f_{k+1,\tau}}(f^{\prime}\,|\:f_{k}^{*})\right]^{ g-1}$\end{document} describes the probability that all other g−1\begin{document}$g-1$\end{document} collectives achieve frequencies above f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} and thus not selected.

Since computing the exact formula of Adults’ f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} distribution in cycle k+1\begin{document}$k+1$\end{document} is hard, we approximate it as Gaussian with mean f¯(τ)\begin{document}$\overline{f}(\tau)$\end{document} and variance σf2(τ)\begin{document}$\sigma_{f}^{2}(\tau)$\end{document}. The Gaussian approximation on Equation 1 requires sharp Gaussian distributions of S(τ)\begin{document}$S(\tau)$\end{document} and F(τ)\begin{document}$F(\tau)$\end{document} (i.e. S¯(τ)≫σs(τ)\begin{document}$\overline{S}(\tau)\gg \sigma_s(\tau)$\end{document} and F¯(τ)≫σF(τ)\begin{document}$\overline{F}(\tau)\gg\sigma_F(\tau)$\end{document}). Compared to Gaussian, the exact S(τ)\begin{document}$S(\tau)$\end{document} (negative binomial) distribution and F(τ)\begin{document}$F(\tau)$\end{document} (Luria-Delbrück) distribution are right-skewed and heavy-tailed. However, these problems are alleviated when the initial numbers of S\begin{document}$S$\end{document} and F\begin{document}$F$\end{document} cells are not small (on the order of 100). Indeed, the sharpness of distributions could be achieved (see Appendix 1—figure 1).

To obtain an analytical solution of the change in f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} over one cycle, we first assume that in a Newborn collective, the number of S cells is distributed as Gaussian with mean S¯0=N0(1−fk∗)\begin{document}$\overline{S}_{0}=N_{0}(1-f_{k}^{*})$\end{document} and variance σS,02=N0fk∗(1−fk∗)\begin{document}$\sigma_{S,0}^{2}=N_{0}f_{k}^{*}(1-f_{k}^{*})$\end{document}. Then, the number of F cells, F0=N0−S0\begin{document}$F_{0}=N_{0}-S_{0}$\end{document}, is distributed as Gaussian with mean F¯0=N0fk∗\begin{document}$\overline{F}_{0}=N_{0}f_{k}^{*}$\end{document} and variance σf,02=N0fk∗(1−fk∗)\begin{document}$\sigma_{f,0}^{2}=N_{0}f_{k}^{*}(1-f_{k}^{*})$\end{document}. From these, we can calculate for Adult collectives the mean and variance of population sizes F(τ)\begin{document}$F(\tau)$\end{document} (i.e. F¯(τ)\begin{document}$\overline{F}(\tau)$\end{document}, σF2(τ)\begin{document}$\sigma_{F}^{2}(\tau)$\end{document}) and S(τ)\begin{document}$S(\tau)$\end{document} (i.e. S¯(τ)\begin{document}$\overline{S}(\tau)$\end{document}, σS2(τ)\begin{document}$\sigma_{S}^{2}(\tau)$\end{document}) (mathematical details in Appendix 1). This task is simplified by the exponential growth of S and F: Rτ=erSτ\begin{document}$R_{\tau}=e^{r_{S}\tau}$\end{document} describes the fold growth of S over maturation time τ\begin{document}$\tau$\end{document}, and since ω\begin{document}$\omega$\end{document} is the fitness advantage of F over S, Wτ=eωτ\begin{document}$W_{\tau}=e^{\omega\tau}$\end{document} describes the fold change of F/S over time τ\begin{document}$\tau$\end{document}. From Rτ\begin{document}$R_{\tau}$\end{document}, Wτ\begin{document}$W_{\tau}$\end{document}, μω\begin{document}$\frac{\mu}{\omega}$\end{document} (mutation rate scaled with the fitness difference), fk∗\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*}$\end{document} (F frequency in the selected collective at cycle k\begin{document}$k$\end{document}), N0\begin{document}$N_{0}$\end{document} (Newborn size), ωrS\begin{document}$\frac{\omega}{r_{S}}$\end{document} (relative fitness advantage), we can calculate the mean and variance of F frequency among the Adults of k+1\begin{document}$k+1$\end{document} cycle (f¯(τ);σf2(τ)\begin{document}$\overline{f}(\tau);\sigma^2_f(\tau)$\end{document}, detailed formula in Equations 48 and 49).

Selection progress - the difference between the median value of the conditional probability distribution Ψ(fk+1∗|fk∗)\begin{document}$\Psi(f_{k+1}^{*}|f_{k}^{*})$\end{document} and the selected frequency of fk∗\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*}$\end{document} (Appendix 2) - can be expressed as:(2)△f=Median[Ψ(fk+1∗|fk∗)]−fk∗=f¯(τ)+[Φ−1(ln⁡2g)]σf(τ)−fk∗,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \triangle f=\mathrm{Median}[\Psi(f_{k+1}^{*}|\:f_{k}^{*})]-f_{k}^{*}=\overline{f}(\tau)+\left[\Phi^{-1}\left(\frac{\ln2}{g}\right)\right]\sigma_{f}(\tau)-f_{k}^{*}, $$\end{document}

where Φ−1(…)\begin{document}$\Phi^{-1}(\ldots)$\end{document} is the inverse cumulative function of standard normal distribution (see main text for an example). We chose the median because compared to the mean, it is easier to get an analytical expression since Φ−1(…)\begin{document}$\Phi^{-1}(\ldots)$\end{document} is known in a closed form. Regardless, using median generated results similar to simulations (Appendix 2—figure 3). As expected, selection progress △f\begin{document}$\triangle f$\end{document} is governed by both the mean (f¯(τ)\begin{document}$\overline{f}(\tau)$\end{document}) and the variation (σf(τ)\begin{document}$\sigma_{f}(\tau)$\end{document}) in f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} among Adults.

When the mutation rate μ=0\begin{document}$\mu=0$\end{document}, f¯(τ)\begin{document}$\overline{f}(\tau)$\end{document} and σf(τ)\begin{document}$\sigma_{f}(\tau)$\end{document} can be simplified to:(3)f¯(τ)=fk∗1−fk∗Wτ+fk∗,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \overline{f}(\tau)=\frac{f_{k}^{*}}{\frac{1-f_{k}^{*}}{W_{\tau}}+f_{k}^{*}},$$\end{document}

In the limit of small fk∗\begin{document}$f^*_{k}$\end{document}, Equation 3 becomes f¯(τ)|fk∗≪1≈fk∗Wτ\begin{document}$\overline f(\tau)|_{f^*_k \ll1}\approx f^*_{k}W_{\tau}$\end{document} while Equation 4 becomes σf2(τ)|fk∗≪1=(2−1RτWτ)fk∗Wτ2/N0\begin{document}$\sigma ^2_f(\tau)|_{f^*_k \ll1}=(2-\frac{1}{R_{\tau}W_{\tau}})f^*_{k}W^2_{\tau}/N_0$\end{document} . Thus, both Newborn size (N0\begin{document}$N_0$\end{document}) and fold-change in F/S during maturation (Wτ\begin{document}$W_{\tau}$\end{document}) are important determinants of selection progress.

sec.p: In contrast, an intermediate target frequency (e.g. f^=0.5\begin{document}$\hat f=0.5$\end{document}; Figure 2b green) is never achievable. High initial F frequencies (e.g. 0.95) decline toward the target but stabilize at the ‘high-threshold’ fH\begin{document}$f^H$\end{document} (∼ 0.7, solid orange line segment in Figure 2a-c) above the target. Low initial F frequencies (e.g. 0) increase toward the target, but then overshoot and stabilize at the fH\begin{document}$f^{H}$\end{document} value.

If the target frequency is low (e.g. f^=0.1\begin{document}$\hat{f}=0.1$\end{document}; Figure 2c dark blue), artificial selection succeeds when the initial frequency is below the ‘lower-threshold’ fL\begin{document}$f^{L}$\end{document} (dotted orange line segment in Figure 2a-c). Initial F frequencies above fL\begin{document}$f^{L}$\end{document} (e.g. 0.45 and 0.95) converge to fH\begin{document}$f^H$\end{document} instead. Initial F frequencies near fL\begin{document}$f^{L}$\end{document} display stochastic trajectories, converging to either fH\begin{document}$f^{H}$\end{document} or f^\begin{document}$\hat{f}$\end{document}.

To achieve target f^\begin{document}$\hat f$\end{document}, inter-collective selection must overcome intra-collective selection. We can visualize the distributions of f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} over two consecutive cycles (bottom to top, Figure 2d) where f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} started above target f^\begin{document}$\hat{f}$\end{document}. When newborns matured into adults, the distribution of f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} up-shifted due to intra-collective selection. The distribution of f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} was then down-shifted toward the target due to inter-collective selection. If the magnitude of down-shift exceeded that of up-shift, progress toward the target was made. During reproduction of collectives, the distribution of f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} retained the same mean but became broader due to stochastic sampling by the Newborns from their parent.

In summary, two regions of target frequencies are ‘accessible’ (gold in Figure 2e, f; Box 1): (1) target frequencies above fH\begin{document}$f^{H}$\end{document} (f^>fH\begin{document}$\hat{f} \gt f^{H}$\end{document}) or (2) target frequencies below fL\begin{document}$f^{L}$\end{document} (f^<fL\begin{document}$\hat{f} \lt f^{L}$\end{document}) and starting at an average frequency below fL\begin{document}$f^{L}$\end{document} (f¯1,0<fL\begin{document}$\overline{f}_{1,0} \lt f^{L}$\end{document}).

sec.title: Intra-collective evolution is the fastest at intermediate F frequencies, creating the ‘waterfall’ phenomenon
sec.p: To understand what gives rise to the two accessible regions, we calculated △f\begin{document}$\triangle f$\end{document}, the selection progress in F frequency over two consecutive cycles (Box 1, Equation 2). The solution (Figure 3a, green) has the same shape as results from numerically integrating Equation 1 (Figure 3a, orange) and from stochastic simulations (Figure 3a, blue).

caption.title: Intra-collective selection and inter-collective selection jointly set the boundaries for selection success.
caption.p: (a) The change in F frequency over one cycle. When fk∗\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*}$\end{document} is sufficiently low or high, inter-collective selection can lower the F frequency to below fk∗\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*}$\end{document} (Δf<0\begin{document}$\Delta f \lt 0$\end{document}). The points where Δf=0\begin{document}$\Delta f=0$\end{document} (in the orange line) are denoted as fL\begin{document}$f^{L}$\end{document} and fH\begin{document}$f^{H}$\end{document}, corresponding to the boundaries in Figure 2. (b) The distributions of frequency differences obtained by 1000 numerical simulations. The cyan, purple, and black box plots respectively indicate the changes in F frequency after intra-collective selection (the mean frequency among the 100 Adults minus the mean frequency among the 100 Newborns during maturation), after inter-collective selection (the frequency of the 1 selected Adult minus the mean frequency among the 100 Adults), and over one selection cycle (the frequency of the selected Adult of one cycle minus that of the previous cycle). The box ranges from 25% to 75% of the distribution, and the median is indicated by a line across the box. The upper and lower whiskers indicate maximum and minimum values of the distribution. ***p<0.001 in an unpaired t\begin{document}$t$\end{document}-test.

sec.p: If △f\begin{document}$\triangle f$\end{document} is negative, then inter-collective selection will succeed in countering intra-collective selection and reducing f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} toward the target. △f\begin{document}$\triangle f$\end{document} is negative if the selected fk∗\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*}$\end{document} is low or high, but not if it is intermediate between fL\begin{document}$f^{L}$\end{document} and fH\begin{document}$f^{H}$\end{document} (Figure 3a). This is because the increase in f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} during maturation is the most drastic when Newborn f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} is intermediate (Figure 3b), for intuitive reasons: when Newborn f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} is low, the increase in f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} will be minor; when Newborn f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} is high, the fitness advantage of F over the population average is small and hence the increase is also minor. Thus, when Newborn F frequency is intermediate, intra-collective selection is the strongest and may overwhelm inter-collective selection (Figure 3b and Appendix 2—figure 2a). Not surprisingly, similar conclusions are derived where S and F are slow-growing and fast-growing species which cannot be converted through mutations (Appendix 4 and Appendix 4—figure 1).

Thus, inter-collective selection is akin to a raftman rowing the raft to a target, while intra-collective selection is akin to a waterfall. This metaphor is best understood in terms of S frequency s=1−f\begin{document}$s=1-f$\end{document}. The lower-threshold fL\begin{document}$f^{L}$\end{document} corresponds to higher-threshold in sH=1−fL\begin{document}$s^{H}=1-f^{L}$\end{document}. Intra-collective selection is akin to a waterfall, driving the S frequency s\begin{document}$s$\end{document} from high to low (Figure 2g). Intra-collective selection acts the strongest when s\begin{document}$s$\end{document} is intermediate (sL<s<sH\begin{document}$s^{L} \lt s \lt \text{s}^{H}$\end{document}), similar to the vertical drop of the fall. Intra-collective selection acts weakly at high (>sH\begin{document}$\gt s^{H}$\end{document}) or low (<sL\begin{document}$\lt s^{L}$\end{document}) s\begin{document}$s$\end{document} , similar to the gentle sloped upper and lower pools of the fall (regions 1 and 2 of Figure 2e and g). Thus, an intermediate target frequency can be impossible to achieve: a raft starting from the upper pool will be flushed down to sL\begin{document}$s^{L}$\end{document} (fH\begin{document}$f^{H}$\end{document}), while a raft starting from the lower pool cannot go beyond sL\begin{document}$s^{L}$\end{document} (fH\begin{document}$f^{H}$\end{document}). In contrast, a low target S frequency (in the lower pool) is always achievable. Finally, a high target S frequency (in the upper pool) can only be achieved if starting from the upper pool (as the raft cannot jump to the upper pool if starting from below).

sec.title: Manipulating experimental setups to expand the achievable target region
sec.p: In Equation 2; Box 1, selection progress △f\begin{document}$\triangle f$\end{document} depends on the total number of collectives under selection (g\begin{document}$g$\end{document}). △f\begin{document}$\triangle f$\end{document} also depends on the mean and the standard deviation of Adult F frequency — f¯(τ)\begin{document}$\overline{f}(\tau)$\end{document} and σf(τ)\begin{document}$\sigma_{f}(\tau)$\end{document}. Equations 3 and 4 of Box 1 provide simplified expressions of f¯(τ)\begin{document}$\overline{f}(\tau)$\end{document} and σf(τ)\begin{document}$\sigma_{f}(\tau)$\end{document} when mutation rate μ\begin{document}$\mu$\end{document} has been set to 0. When the mutation rate μ\begin{document}$\mu$\end{document} is not zero (Equations 48 and 49 in Appendix 2), selection progress is additionally influenced by μω\begin{document}$\frac{\mu}{\omega}$\end{document} (mutation rate μ\begin{document}$\mu$\end{document} scaled with fitness difference ω\begin{document}$\omega$\end{document}).

Our goal is to make △f\begin{document}$\triangle f$\end{document} as negative as possible so that any increase in f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} during collective maturation may be reduced. From Equation 2 in Box 1, a small f¯(τ)\begin{document}$\overline{f}(\tau)$\end{document} will facilitate collective-level selection. Additionally, a large σf(τ)\begin{document}$\sigma_{f}(\tau)$\end{document} will also facilitate collective-level selection due to negative Φ−1(ln⁡2g)\begin{document}$\Phi^{-1}\left(\frac{\ln 2}{g}\right)$\end{document}. Note that since ln⁡2g\begin{document}$\frac{\ln 2}{g}$\end{document}<0.5 for g≥2\begin{document}$g\geq 2$\end{document}, Φ−1(ln⁡2g)\begin{document}$\Phi^{-1}\left(\frac{\ln 2}{g}\right)$\end{document} — corresponding to the number y\begin{document}$y$\end{document} such that the probability of a standard normal random variable being less than or equal to y\begin{document}$y$\end{document} is ln⁡2g\begin{document}$\frac{\ln 2}{g}$\end{document} — is negative.

From Equation 4 in Box 1, σf(τ)\begin{document}$\sigma_{f}(\tau)$\end{document} will be large if Newborn size N0\begin{document}$N_{0}$\end{document} is small. Indeed, as Newborn size N0\begin{document}$N_{0}$\end{document} declines, the region of achievable target frequency expands (gold area in Figure 4a). If the Newborn size N0\begin{document}$N_{0}$\end{document} is sufficiently small (e.g. ≤ 700 in our parameter regime), any target frequency can be reached. An analytical approximation of the maximal Newborn size permissible for all target frequencies is given in Appendix 3.

caption.title: Expanding the region of success for artificial collective selection.
caption.p: (a) Reducing the population size in Newborn N0\begin{document}$N_{0}$\end{document} expands the region of success. In the gold area, the probability that fk+1∗\begin{document}$f_{k+1}^{*}$\end{document} becomes smaller than fk∗\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*}$\end{document} in a cycle is more than 50%. We used g=10\begin{document}$g=10$\end{document} and τ≈4.8\begin{document}$\tau\approx 4.8$\end{document}. Figures 2–3 correspond to N˘0=1000\begin{document}$\breve{N}_{0}=1000$\end{document} in this graph. Black dotted line indicates the critical Newborn size below which all target frequencies can be achieved. (b) Increasing the total number of collectives g\begin{document}$g$\end{document} also expands the region of success, although only slightly. We used a fixed Newborn size N0=1000\begin{document}$N_{0}=1000$\end{document}. The maturation time τ=log⁡(100)/rS≈9.2\begin{document}$\tau=\log(100)/r_{S}\approx 9.2$\end{document} is set to be long enough so that an Adult can generate at least 100 Newborns. (c) Increasing the maturation time shrinks the region of success. We used a fixed Newborn size N0=1000\begin{document}$N_0=1000$\end{document} and number of collectives g=10\begin{document}$g=10$\end{document}.

sec.p: From Equations 3 and 4 in Box 1, maturation time τ\begin{document}$\tau$\end{document} affects f¯(τ)\begin{document}$\overline{f}(\tau)$\end{document} and σf(τ)\begin{document}$\sigma_{f}(\tau)$\end{document} through Wτ=eωτ\begin{document}$W_{\tau}=e^{\omega\tau}$\end{document} (the fold change in F/S over τ\begin{document}$\tau$\end{document}), and affects σf(τ)\begin{document}$\sigma_{f}(\tau)$\end{document} additionally through Rτ=erSτ\begin{document}$R_{\tau}=e^{r_{S}\tau}$\end{document} (fold-growth of S over τ\begin{document}$\tau$\end{document}). Longer τ\begin{document}$\tau$\end{document} increases f¯(τ)\begin{document}$\overline{f}(\tau)$\end{document} and is thus detrimental to selection progress. The relationship between σf(τ)\begin{document}$\sigma_{f}(\tau)$\end{document} and τ\begin{document}$\tau$\end{document} is not monotonic (Appendix 2—figure 2c), meaning that an intermediate value of τ\begin{document}$\tau$\end{document} is the best for achieving large σf(τ)\begin{document}$\sigma_{f}(\tau)$\end{document}. However, the effect of f¯(τ)\begin{document}$\overline{f}(\tau)$\end{document} dominates that of σf(τ)\begin{document}$\sigma_{f}(\tau)$\end{document} and therefore, the region of success monotonically reduces with longer maturation time (Figure 4c). Similarly, f¯(τ)\begin{document}$\overline{f}(\tau)$\end{document} will be small if ω\begin{document}$\omega$\end{document} (fitness advantage of F over S) is small. Indeed, as ω\begin{document}$\omega$\end{document} becomes larger, the region of success becomes smaller (Appendix 5—figure 1).

g\begin{document}$g$\end{document}, the number of collectives under selection, also affects selection outcomes. As g\begin{document}$g$\end{document} increases, the value of Φ−1(ln⁡2g)\begin{document}$\Phi^{-1}\left(\frac{\ln 2}{g}\right)$\end{document} becomes more negative, and so does △f\begin{document}$\triangle f$\end{document} — meaning collective-level selection will be more effective. Intuitively, with more collectives, the chance of finding a f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} closer to the target is more likely. Thus, a larger number of collectives broadens the region of success (Figure 4b). However, the effect of g\begin{document}$g$\end{document} is not dramatic. To see why, we note that the only place that g\begin{document}$g$\end{document} appears is Equation 2 in Φ−1(1g)\begin{document}$\Phi^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{g}\right)$\end{document}. When g\begin{document}$g$\end{document} becomes large, Φ−1(1g)\begin{document}$\Phi^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{g}\right)$\end{document} is asymptotically expressed as Φ−1(1g)≈−2ln⁡g−ln⁡[ln⁡g]+⋯\begin{document}$\Phi^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{g}\right)\approx-\sqrt{2\ln g-\ln[\ln g]+\cdots}$\end{document} (Appendix 2) (Phllip, 1960), and thus does not change dramatically as g\begin{document}$g$\end{document} varies.

sec.title: The waterfall phenomenon in a higher dimension
sec.p: To examine the waterfall effect in a higher dimension, we investigate a three-population system where a faster-growing population (FF) grows faster than the fast-growing population (F) which grows faster than the slow-growing population (S) (Figure 5a and Appendix 8—figure 1). In the three-population case, the evolutionary trajectory travels in a two-dimensional plane. A target population composition can be achieved if inter-collective selection can sufficiently reduce the frequencies of F as well as FF (accessible regions, gold in Figure 5b).

caption.title: In higher dimensions, the success of artificial selection requires the entire evolutionary trajectory remaining in the accessible region.
caption.p: (a) During collective maturation, a slow-growing population (S) (with growth rate rS\begin{document}$r_{S}$\end{document}; light gray) can mutate to a fast-growing population (F) (with growth rate rS+ω\begin{document}$r_{S}+\omega$\end{document}; medium gray), which can mutate further into a faster-growing population (FF) (with growth rate rS+2ω\begin{document}$r_{S}+2\omega$\end{document}; dark gray). Here, the rates of both mutational steps are μ\begin{document}$\mu$\end{document}, and ω>0\begin{document}$\omega \gt 0$\end{document}. (b) Evolutionary trajectories from various initial compositions (open circles) to various targets (filled triangles). Intra-collective evolution favors FF over F (vertical blue arrow) over S (horizontal blue arrow). The accessible regions are marked gold (see Appendix 1). We obtain final compositions starting from several initial compositions while aiming for different target compositions in i, ii, and iii. The evolutionary trajectories are shown in dots with color gradients from initial time (light grey) to final time (dark grey). (i) A target composition with a high FF frequency is always achievable. (ii) A target composition with intermediate FF frequency is never achievable. (iii) A target composition with low FF frequency is achievable only if starting from an appropriate initial composition such that the entire trajectory never meanders away from the accessible region. The figures are drawn using the mpltern package (Ikeda et al., 2019). (c) The accessible region in the three-population problem is interpreted as an extension of the two-population problem. First, the accessible region between FF and S+F is given, and then the S+F region is stretched into S and F.

sec.p: From numerical simulations, we identified two accessible regions: a small region near FF and a band region spanning from S to F (gold in Figure 5b i). Intuitively, the rate at which FF grows faster than S+F is greater than the rate at which F grows faster than S (see Appendix 8). Thus, the problem can initially be reduced to a two-population problem (i.e. FF versus F+S; Figure 5c left), and then expanded to a three-population problem (Figure 5c right).

Similar to the two-population case, targets in the inaccessible region are never achievable (Figure 5b ii), while those in the FF region are always achievable (Figure 5b i). Strikingly, a target composition in an accessible region may not be achievable even when the initial composition is within the same region: once the composition escapes the accessible region, the trajectory cannot return back to the accessible region (Figure 5biii, the leftmost initial condition). However, if the initial position is closer to the target in the accessible region, the target becomes achievable (Figure 5b iii, initial condition near the bottom). Note that here, the selection outcome is path-dependent in the sense of being sensitive to initial conditions. This phenomenon is distinct from hysteresis, where path-dependence results from whether a tuning parameter is increased or decreased.

In conclusion, we have investigated the evolutionary trajectories of population compositions in collectives under selection, which are governed by intra-collective selection (which favors fast-growing populations) and inter-collective selection (which, in our case, strives to counter fast-growing populations). Intra-collective selection has the strongest effect at intermediate frequencies of faster-growing populations, potentially creating an inaccessible region of target frequency analogous to the vertical drop of a waterfall. High and low target frequencies are both accessible, analogous to the lower and the upper pools of a waterfall, respectively. A less challenging target (high f^\begin{document}$\hat{f}$\end{document}; low s^\begin{document}$\hat{s}$\end{document}) is achievable from any initial position. In contrast, a more challenging target (low f^\begin{document}$\hat{f}$\end{document}; high s^\begin{document}$\hat{s}$\end{document}) is only achievable if the entire trajectory is contained within the region, similar to a raft striving to reach a point in the upper pool must start at and remain in the upper pool. Our work suggests that the strength of intra-collective selection is not constant, and that strategically choosing an appropriate starting point can be essential for successful collective selection.

sec.title: Stochastic simulations
sec.p: A selection cycle is composed of three steps: maturation, selection, and reproduction. At the beginning of the cycle k\begin{document}$k$\end{document}, a collective i\begin{document}$i$\end{document} has Sk,0(i)\begin{document}$S_{k,0}^{(i)}$\end{document} slow-growing cells and Fk,0(i)\begin{document}$F_{k,0}^{(i)}$\end{document} fast-growing cells. At the first cycle, the mean F frequency of collectives is set to be f¯1,0. F1,0(i)\begin{document}$\overline{f}_{1,0}.\ F^{(i)}_{1,0}$\end{document} is sampled from the binomial distribution with mean N0f¯1,0\begin{document}$N_{0}\overline{f}_{1,0}$\end{document}. Then, S1,0(i)(=N0−F1,0(i))\begin{document}$S_{1,0}^{(i)}(=N_{0}-F_{1,0}^{(i)})$\end{document} S cells are in the collective i\begin{document}$i$\end{document}. In the maturation step, we calculate Sk,τ(i)\begin{document}$S_{k,\tau}^{(i)}$\end{document} and Fk,τ(i)\begin{document}$F_{k,\tau}^{(i)}$\end{document} by using stochastic simulation. We can simulate the division and mutation of each individual cell stochastically by using the tau-leaping algorithm (Gillespie, 2001; Cao et al., 2006; see Appendix 1—figure 3). However, individual-based simulations require a long computing time. Instead, we randomly sample Sk,τ(i)\begin{document}$S_{k,\tau}^{(i)}$\end{document} and Fk,τ(i)\begin{document}$F_{k,\tau}^{(i)}$\end{document} from the joint probability density distribution P(Sk,τ(i),Fk,τ(i))\begin{document}$P(S_{k,\tau}^{(i)},F_{k,\tau}^{(i)})$\end{document}. To obtain P(Sk,τ(i),Fk,τ(i))\begin{document}$P(S_{k,\tau}^{(i)},F_{k,\tau}^{(i)})$\end{document}, we solve the master equation which describes the time evolution of the probability distribution P(Sk,t(i),Fk,t(i))\begin{document}$P(S_{k,t}^{(i)},F_{k,t}^{(i)})$\end{document} under the random processes (see Appendix 1). We assumed that Sk,τ(i) and Fk,τ(i)\begin{document}$S_{k,\tau}^{(i)}\text{ and }F_{k,\tau}^{(i)}$\end{document} are independent (as S and F populations grow independently without ecological interactions), and thus P(Sk,τ(i),Fk,τ(i))\begin{document}$P(S_{k,\tau}^{(i)},F_{k,\tau}^{(i)})$\end{document} is product of two probability density functions P(Sk,τ(i)) and P(Fk,τ(i))\begin{document}$P(S_{k,\tau}^{(i)})\text{ and }P(F_{k,\tau}^{(i)})$\end{document}. Each distribution follows a Gaussian distribution, with the mean and variance numerically obtained from ordinary differential equations derived from the master equation (see Appendix 1). We choose the collective with the closest frequency to the target f^\begin{document}$\hat{f}$\end{document} to generates g\begin{document}$g$\end{document} Newborns. The number of F cells is sampled from the binomial distribution with the mean of N0fk∗\begin{document}$N_{0}f_{k}^{*}$\end{document}. We start a new cycle with those Newborn collectives. Then, the number of S cells in a collective i\begin{document}$i$\end{document} is Sk+1,0(i)=N0−Fk+1,0(i)\begin{document}$S_{k+1,0}^{(i)}=N_{0}-F_{k+1,0}^{(i)}$\end{document}.

sec.title: Analytical approach to the conditional probability
sec.p: The conditional probability distribution Ψ(fk+1∗|fk∗)\begin{document}$\Psi(f_{k+1}^{*}|f_{k}^{*})$\end{document} of observing fk+1∗\begin{document}$f_{k+1}^{*}$\end{document} at a given fk∗\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*}$\end{document} is calculated by the following procedure. Given the selected collective in cycle k\begin{document}$k$\end{document} with fk∗\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*}$\end{document}, the collective-level reproduction proceeds by sampling g\begin{document}$g$\end{document} Newborn collectives with N0\begin{document}$N_{0}$\end{document} cells in cycle k+1\begin{document}$k+1$\end{document}. Each Newborn collective contains certain F numbers Fk+1,0(1),⋯,Fk+1,0(g)\begin{document}$F_{k+1,0}^{(1)}, \cdots ,F_{k+1,0}^{(g)}$\end{document} at the beginning of the cycle k+1\begin{document}$k+1$\end{document}, which can be mapped into fk+1,0(1),⋯,fk+1,0(g)\begin{document}$f_{k+1,0}^{\,(1)}, \cdots,f_{k+1,0}^{\,(g)}$\end{document} with the constraint of N0\begin{document}$N_{0}$\end{document} cells. If the number of cells in the selected collective is large enough, the joint conditional distribution function P(fk+1,0(1),⋯,fk+1,0(g)|fk∗)\begin{document}$P\left(f_{k+1,0}^{\, (1)},\cdots,f_{k+1,0}^{\, (g)}|f_{k}^{*}\right)$\end{document} is well described by the product of g\begin{document}$g$\end{document} independent and identical Gaussian distribution N(μ,σ2)\begin{document}$\mathcal{N}(\mu,\sigma^{2})$\end{document}. So we consider the frequencies of g\begin{document}$g$\end{document} Newborn collectives as g\begin{document}$g$\end{document} identical copies of the Gaussian random variable fk+1,0\begin{document}$f_{k+1,0}$\end{document}. The mean and variance of fk+1,0\begin{document}$f_{k+1,0}$\end{document} are given by m=fk∗\begin{document}$m=f_{k}^{*}$\end{document} and σ2=fk∗(1−fk∗)/N0\begin{document}$\sigma^{2}=f_{k}^{*}(1-f_{k}^{*})/N_{0}$\end{document}. Then, the conditional probability distribution function of fk+1,0\begin{document}$f_{k+1,0}$\end{document} being ζ\begin{document}$\zeta$\end{document} is given by(5)Pfk+1,0(ζ|fk∗)=12πexp⁡(−(ζ−m)22σ2).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle P_{f_{k+1,0}}(\zeta|f_{k}^{*})=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\exp\left(-\frac{(\zeta-m)^{2}}{2\sigma^{2}}\right).$$\end{document}

After the reproduction step, the Newborn collectives grow for time τ\begin{document}$\tau$\end{document}. The frequency is changed from the given frequency ζ\begin{document}$\zeta$\end{document} to f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} by division and mutation processes. We assume that the frequency f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} of an Adult is also approximated by a Gaussian random variable N(f¯(τ),σf2(τ))\begin{document}$\mathcal{N}(\overline{f}(\tau),\sigma_{f}^{2}(\tau))$\end{document}. The mean f¯(τ)\begin{document}$\overline{f}(\tau)$\end{document} and variance σf2(τ)\begin{document}$\sigma^2_f(\tau)$\end{document} are calculated by using means and variances of S\begin{document}$S$\end{document} and F\begin{document}$F$\end{document} (see Appendix 2). Since f¯(τ)\begin{document}$\overline{f}(\tau)$\end{document} and σf2(τ)\begin{document}$\sigma_{f}^{2}(\tau)$\end{document} also depend on ζ\begin{document}$\zeta$\end{document}, the conditional probability distribution function of fk+1,τ\begin{document}$f_{k+1,\tau}$\end{document} being f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} is given by(6)Pfk+1,τ(f|ζ)=12πexp⁡(−(f−f¯(τ))22σf2(τ)).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle P_{f_{k+1,\tau}}(f|\zeta)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\exp\left(-\frac{(f-\overline{f}(\tau))^{2}}{2\sigma_{f}^{2}(\tau)}\right). $$\end{document}

The conditional probability distribution of an Adult collective in cycle k+1\begin{document}$k+1$\end{document} (fk+1,τ\begin{document}$f_{k+1,\tau}$\end{document}) to have frequency f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} at a given fk∗\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*}$\end{document} is calculated by multiplying two Gaussian distribution functions and integrating overall ζ\begin{document}$\zeta$\end{document} values, which is given by(7)Pfk+1,τ(f|fk∗)=∫01dζ Pfk+1,τ(f|ζ) Pfk+1,0(ζ|fk∗).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle P_{f_{k+1,\tau}}(f|f_{k}^{*})=\int_{0}^{1}d\zeta\ P_{f_{k+1,\tau}}(f|\zeta)\ P_{f_{k+1,0}}(\zeta|f_{k}^{*}).$$\end{document}

Since we select the minimum frequency fk+1min\begin{document}$f_{k+1}^{\, \min}$\end{document} among g\begin{document}$g$\end{document} identical copies of fk+1,τ\begin{document}$f_{k+1,\tau}$\end{document}, the conditional probability distribution function of fk+1min\begin{document}$f_{k+1}^{\, \min}$\end{document} follows a minimum value distribution, which is given in Equation 1. Here, for the case of f^<fk∗\begin{document}$\hat{f} \ltf_{k}^{*}$\end{document}, the selected frequency fk+1,0\begin{document}$f_{k+1,0}$\end{document} is the minimum frequency fk+1min\begin{document}$f_{k+1}^{\, \min}$\end{document}. So we have Ψ(fk+1∗|fk∗)\begin{document}$\Psi(f_{k+1}^{*}|f_{k}^{*})$\end{document} by replacing fk+1min\begin{document}$f_{k+1}^{\, \min}$\end{document} with fk+1∗\begin{document}$f_{k+1}^{*}$\end{document}.

We assume that the conditional probability distribution in Equation 7 follows a normal distribution, whose mean and variances are described by Equation 48 and Equation 49. Then, the extreme value theory (Gumbel, 1958) estimates the median of the selected Adult by(8)Median(fk+1∗)=f¯(τ)+[Φ−1(ln⁡2g)]σf(τ).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \text{Median}(f_{k+1}^{*})=\overline{f}(\tau)+\left[\Phi^{-1}(\frac{\ln2}{g})\right]\sigma_{f}(\tau).$$\end{document}
The selection progress Δf\begin{document}$\Delta f$\end{document} in Equation 2 is obtained by subtracting fk∗\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*}$\end{document} from Equation 8.
