sec.title: Stochastic simulation of the selection cycle
sec.p: In the main text, we design a simple model of artificial selection on collectives. The selection cycle starts with g\begin{document}$g$\end{document} ‘Newborn’ collectives which consist of two populations - slow-growing population (S) and fast-growing population (F). S mutates to F at a rate μ\begin{document}$\mu$\end{document}. The newborns mature for a fixed time τ\begin{document}$\tau$\end{document}. The matured collective (‘Adult’) with the highest function (with F frequency f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} closest to the target f^\begin{document}$\hat{f}$\end{document}) is chosen to reproduce g\begin{document}$g$\end{document} Newborn collectives, each with N0\begin{document}$N_{0}$\end{document} cells.

In our selection cycle, variation among collectives mainly resulted from demographic noises during cell birth, cell mutation, and collective reproduction. In this section, we provide details of the simulation.

sec.title: Maturation
sec.p: Here, we calculate the cell numbers during maturation. Each collective i\begin{document}$i$\end{document} (i=1,…,g\begin{document}$i=1,\dots,g$\end{document}) has Sk,t(i)\begin{document}$S_{k,\text{t}}^{(i)}$\end{document} S cells and Fk,t(i)\begin{document}$F_{k,t}^{(i)}$\end{document} F cells where k\begin{document}$k$\end{document} is the cycle number and t\begin{document}$t$\end{document} indicates time (0≤t≤τ\begin{document}$0\leq t\leq\tau$\end{document}). At the beginning of cycle k\begin{document}$k$\end{document} (t=0\begin{document}$t=0$\end{document}), each Newborn collective has a total of N0=Sk,0(i)+Fk,0(i)\begin{document}$N_{0}=S_{k,0}^{(i)}+F_{k,0}^{(i)}$\end{document} cells. The collectives are allowed to ‘mature’ for t=τ\begin{document}$t=\tau$\end{document} during which S and F grow at rates rS\begin{document}$r_{S}$\end{document} and rS+ω\begin{document}$r_{S}+\omega$\end{document} (ω>0\begin{document}$\omega \gt 0$\end{document}), respectively. In this subsection, we ignore the cycle number index k\begin{document}$k$\end{document} and the collective index k\begin{document}$k$\end{document} for convenience. That is, we denote Sk,t(i)\begin{document}$S_{k,t}^{(i)}$\end{document} and Fk,t(i)\begin{document}$F_{k,t}^{(i)}$\end{document} as S(t)\begin{document}$S(t)$\end{document} and F(t)\begin{document}$F(t)$\end{document}, respectively.

We describe cell divisions of S and F cells and mutation from S to F with the following chemical reaction rules:(9)S→rSS+S,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \text{S} \xrightarrow{r_{S}} \text{S}+\text{S}, $$\end{document}(10)F→ω>0rS+ωF+F,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \text{F} \xrightarrow[\omega \gt 0]{r_{S}+\omega} \text{F}+\text{F},$$\end{document}(11)S→μF,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \text{S} \xrightarrow{\mu} \text{F},$$\end{document}

One can run an individual-based simulation by counting the number of events occurring during collective maturation via the tau-leaping algorithm (Gillespie, 2001; Cao et al., 2006) to generate a sample trajectory of S(t)\begin{document}$S(t)$\end{document} and F(t)\begin{document}$F(t)$\end{document} for each collective. However, the individual-based simulation requires long computing times due to a large number of random events to be counted. Hence, we used a ‘sampling method’ by sampling the numbers of S and F cells in collectives from a joint probability density distribution (jpdf) P(S,F,t)\begin{document}$P(S,F,t)$\end{document} which denotes the probability density to have S\begin{document}$S$\end{document} number of S cells and fk+1,0\begin{document}$f_{k+1,0}$\end{document} number of F cells at time t\begin{document}$t$\end{document} in the cycle. To do so, we require an analytical expression of P(S,F,t)\begin{document}$P(S,F,t)$\end{document}.

First, we assume that the chemical reactions in Equations 9–11 occur independently, and never occur simultaneously within a short time interval [t,t+dt)\begin{document}$[t,t+dt)$\end{document}. Then, the differential of P(S,F,t)\begin{document}$P(S,F,t)$\end{document} with respect to time is given by(12)dP(S,F,t)dt=rS(S−1)P(S−1,F,t)+(rS+ω)(F−1)P(S,F−1,t)+μ(S+1)P(S+1,F−1,t)−(rSS+(rS+ω)F+μS)P(S,F,t).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{dP(S,F,t)}{dt} =\, & r_{S}(S-1)P(S-1,F,t)\\ & +(r_{S}+\omega)(F-1)P(S,F-1,t)\\ & +\mu(S+1)P(S+1,F-1,t)\\ & -(r_{S}S+(r_{S}+\omega)F+\mu S)P(S,F,t).$$\end{document}

This master equation describes a probability density ‘flux’ at the state (S,F)\begin{document}$(S,F)$\end{document}. The first term describes the scenario where a single birth event of a S cell happens during time interval [t,t+dt)\begin{document}$[t,t+dt)$\end{document}, which changes the collective’s composition from (S−1,F)\begin{document}$(S-1,F)$\end{document} to (S,F)\begin{document}$(S,F)$\end{document}. Similarly, the second term comes from a birth event of an F cell. The third term indicates the mutation event from (S+1,F−1)\begin{document}$(S+1,F-1)$\end{document} to (S,F)\begin{document}$(S,F)$\end{document}. The last term corresponds to the outflow of probability density by birth and mutation processes, which describes the changes from (S,F)\begin{document}$(S,F)$\end{document} to any other states.

Calculating the exact form of P(S,F,t)\begin{document}$P(S,F,t)$\end{document} is not simple. Instead, we assume that the mutation rate is much smaller than the growth rates, and hence the correlation between S\begin{document}$S$\end{document} and F\begin{document}$F$\end{document} is sufficiently small. Additionally, S and F do not interact ecologically. Then, we can express P(S,F,t)\begin{document}$P(S,F,t)$\end{document} as a product of two probability density functions (pdf) of S(t)\begin{document}$S(t)$\end{document} and F(t)\begin{document}$F(t)$\end{document}, P(S,F,t)=P(S,t)P(F,t)\begin{document}$P(S,F,t)=P(S,t)P(F,t)$\end{document}. We assume that each pdf of S\begin{document}$S$\end{document} and F\begin{document}$F$\end{document} can be approximated as Gaussian (N\begin{document}$\mathcal{N}$\end{document}), which is supported by the Central Limit Theorem and Appendix 1—figure 1. In more detail, the cell numbers S\begin{document}$S$\end{document} and F\begin{document}$F$\end{document} are mainly determined by growth (Equations 9; 10), and also mutations (Equation 11). Even though the number of events would be different among different realizations, the mean numbers of events will follow Gaussian distributions. So, we can simply assume that the distributions of cell numbers also follow Gaussian distributions. This assumption requires that the distributions have insignificant skewness and no heavy tails, which we will numerically check afterwards. The pdfs of S(t)\begin{document}$S(t)$\end{document} and F(t)\begin{document}$F(t)$\end{document} are given by(13)P(S,t)=12πσS2(t)e−(S(t)−S¯(t))22σS2(t)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle P(S,t)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma_{S}^{2}(t)}}e^{-\frac{(S(t)-\overline{S}(t))^{2}}{2\sigma_{S}^{2}(t)}} $$\end{document}
and(14)P(F,t)=12πσF2(t)e−(F(t)−F¯(t))22σF2(t).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle P(F,t)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma_{F}^{2}(t)}}e^{-\frac{(F(t)-\overline{F}(t))^{2}}{2\sigma_{F}^{2}(t)}}.$$\end{document}

That is, P(S,F,t)\begin{document}$P(S,F,t)$\end{document} is written as(15)P(S,F,t)=12πσS2(t)12πσF2(t)e−(S(t)−S¯(t))22σS2(t)−(F(t)−F¯(t))22σF2(t).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle P(S,F,t)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma_{S}^{2}(t)}}\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma_{F}^{2}(t)}}e^{-\frac{(S(t)-\overline{S}(t))^{2}}{2\sigma_{S}^{2}(t)}-\frac{(F(t)-\overline{F}(t))^{2}}{2\sigma_{F}^{2}(t)}}.$$\end{document}

Now we need means (S¯(t)\begin{document}$\overline{S}(t)$\end{document} and F¯(t)\begin{document}$\overline{F}(t)$\end{document}) and variances (σs2(t)\begin{document}$\sigma^2_s(t)$\end{document} and σF2(t)\begin{document}$\sigma_{F}^{2}(t)$\end{document}) of S and F cell numbers to express the distribution analytically.

The means are defined by S¯(t)=∑S=0∞∑F=0∞SP(S,F,t)\begin{document}$\overline{S}(t)=\sum_{S=0}^{\infty}\sum_{F=0}^{\infty}S\,P(S,F,t)$\end{document} and F¯(t)=∑S=0∞∑F=0∞FP(S,F,t)\begin{document}$\overline{F}(t)=\sum_{S=0}^{\infty}\sum_{F=0}^{\infty}F\,P(S,F,t)$\end{document}. The differential equations for means are obtained by applying the definition to the master equation in Equation 12, as(16)dS¯(t)dt=rSS¯(t)−μS¯(t),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{d\overline{S}(t)}{dt} = r_{S}\overline{S}(t)-\mu\overline{S}(t),$$\end{document}(17)dF¯(t)dt=(rS+ω)F¯(t)+μS¯(t).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{d\overline{F}(t)}{dt} = (r_{S}+\omega)\overline{F}(t)+\mu\overline{S}(t).$$\end{document}

We assume that the mutation rate μ\begin{document}$\mu$\end{document} is much smaller than rS\begin{document}$r_{S}$\end{document} and ω\begin{document}$\omega$\end{document}. By solving Equation 16 and Equation 17, the means S¯(t)\begin{document}$\overline{S}(t)$\end{document} and F¯(t)\begin{document}$\overline{F}(t)$\end{document} are given by(18)S¯(t)=S¯oe(rS−μ)t≈S¯oerSt,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \overline{S}(t) = \overline{S}_{o}e^{(r_{S}-\mu)t}\approx\overline{S}_{o}e^{r_{S}t},$$\end{document}(19)F¯(t)=F¯oe(rS+ω)t+μS¯oω+μ(e(rS+ω)t−e(rS−μ)t)≈F¯oe(rS+ω)t+μS¯oω(e(rS+ω)t−erSt),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \overline{F}(t) = \overline{F}_{o}e^{(r_{S}+\omega)t}+\frac{\mu\overline{S}_{o}}{\omega+\mu}\left(e^{(r_{S}+\omega)t}-e^{(r_{S}-\mu)t}\right)\approx\overline{F}_{o}e^{(r_{S}+\omega)t}+\frac{\mu\overline{S}_{o}}{\omega}\left(e^{(r_{S}+\omega)t}-e^{r_{S}t}\right), $$\end{document}

where S¯o≡S¯(0)\begin{document}$\overline{S}_{o}\equiv\overline{S}(0)$\end{document} and F¯o≡F¯(0)\begin{document}$\overline{F}_{o}\equiv\overline{F}(0)$\end{document} are the mean numbers of S and F cells at the beginning of cycle, t=0\begin{document}$t=0$\end{document}. Note that the second term of Equation 19 is consistent with previous studies (Zheng, 1999). Now we introduce factors Rt=erSt\begin{document}$R_{t}=e^{r_St}$\end{document} and Wt=eωt\begin{document}$W_{t}=e^{\omega t}$\end{document} in Equations 18; 19 in order to simplify the formula. Rt\begin{document}$R_t$\end{document} is the multiplying factor by which the S cell number increases after time t\begin{document}$t$\end{document}. Wt\begin{document}$W_t$\end{document} is the fold change in F/S\begin{document}$F/S$\end{document}. Then, we can rewrite(20)S¯(t)=S¯oRt,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \overline{S}(t) = \overline{S}_{o}R_{t}, $$\end{document}(21)F¯(t)=F¯oRtWt+μS¯oωRt(Wt−1).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \overline{F}(t) = \overline{F}_{o}R_{t}W_{t}+\frac{\mu\overline{S}_{o}}{\omega}R_{t}(W_{t}-1).$$\end{document}

We define the second momenta of S\begin{document}$S$\end{document} and F\begin{document}$F$\end{document} as(22)S2¯=∑S=0∞∑F=0∞S2P(S,F,t),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \overline{S^{2}}=\sum_{S=0}^{\infty}\sum_{F=0}^{\infty}S^{2}P(S,F,t), $$\end{document}(23)F2¯=∑S=0∞∑F=0∞F2P(S,F,t).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \overline{F^{2}}=\sum_{S=0}^{\infty}\sum_{F=0}^{\infty}F^{2}P(S,F,t). $$\end{document}

Then, the corresponding differential equations are given by(24)dS2¯dt=2(rS−μ)S2¯+(rS+μ)S¯,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{d\overline{S^{2}}}{dt} = 2(r_{S}-\mu)\overline{S^{2}}+(r_{S}+\mu)\overline{S}, $$\end{document}(25)dF2¯dt=2(rS+ω)F2¯+(rS+ω)F¯+2μS¯F¯+μS¯.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{d\overline{F^{2}}}{dt} = 2(r_{S}+\omega)\overline{F^{2}}+(r_{S}+\omega)\overline{F}+2\mu\overline{S}\overline{F}+\mu\overline{S}. $$\end{document}

The solution of Equation 24 is(26)S2¯(t)=rS+μμ−rSS¯o[e(μ−rS)t−1]e2(rS−μ)t+S2¯oe2(rS−μ)t\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \overline{S^{2}}(t) = \frac{r_{S}+\mu}{\mu-r_{S}}\overline{S}_{o}\left[e^{(\mu-r_{S})t}-1\right]e^{2(r_{S}-\mu)t}+\overline{S^{2}}_{o}e^{2(r_{S}-\mu)t}$$\end{document}(27)≈So2¯e2rSt+S¯oerSt(erSt−1),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \approx \overline{S_{o}^{2}}e^{2r_{S}t}+\overline{S}_{o}e^{r_{S}t}(e^{r_{S}t}-1), $$\end{document}

where So2¯≡S2¯(0)\begin{document}$\overline{S^{2}_o}\equiv\overline{S^{2}}(0)$\end{document} is the second moment of initial values. Thus, the variance σS2(t)=S2¯(t)−[S¯(t)]2\begin{document}$\sigma_{S}^{2}(t)=\overline{S^{2}}(t)-[\overline{S}(t)]^{2}$\end{document} is(28)σS2(t)=σS,02e2rSt+S¯oerSt(erSt−1)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \sigma_{S}^{2}(t) =\sigma_{S,0}^{2}e^{2r_{S}t}+\overline{S}_{o}e^{r_{S}t}(e^{r_{S}t}-1)\nonumber$$\end{document}(29)=σS,02Rt2+S¯oRt(Rt−1)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle =\sigma_{S,0}^{2}R_{t}^{2}+\overline{S}_{o}R_{t}(R_{t}-1) $$\end{document}

where σS,02≡σS2(0)\begin{document}$\sigma_{S,0}^{2}\equiv\sigma_{S}^{2}(0)$\end{document} is a variance of S cell numbers at t=0\begin{document}$t=0$\end{document}. In Equation 25, we require SF¯(t)=∑S=0∞∑F=0∞SFP(S,F,t)\begin{document}$\overline{SF}(t)=\sum_{S=0}^{\infty}\sum_{F=0}^{\infty}SFP(S,F,t)$\end{document} to calculate F2¯(t)\begin{document}$\overline{F^{2}}(t)$\end{document}. Equation 12 provides a differential equation for SF¯(t)\begin{document}$\overline{SF}(t)$\end{document} as(30)dSF¯dt=(2rS+ω−μ)SF¯+μ(S2¯−S¯).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{d\overline{SF}}{dt}=(2r_{S}+\omega-\mu)\overline{SF}+\mu\left(\overline{S^{2}}-\overline{S}\right).$$\end{document}

The solution of Equation 30 is given by(31)SF¯(t)=SF¯oe(2rS+ω)t+μω(S2¯0+S¯0)(e(2rS+ω)t−e2rSt)−2μS¯0rS+ω(e(2rS+ω)t−erSt).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \overline{SF}(t) = &\, \overline{SF}_{o}e^{(2r_{S}+\omega)t}\\ & +\frac{\mu}{\omega}\left(\overline{S^{2}}_{0}+\overline{S}_{0}\right)\left(e^{(2r_{S}+\omega)t}-e^{2r_{S}t}\right) \\ & -\frac{2\mu\overline{S}_{0}}{r_{S}+\omega}\left(e^{(2r_{S}+\omega)t}-e^{r_{S}t}\right). $$\end{document}

By using Equation 31, the solution of Equation 25 is given by(32)F2¯(t)=F2¯0e2(rS+ω)t+F¯0e(rS+ω)t(e(rS+ω)t−1)+μS¯oω(2ωr+2ωe2(rS+ω)t−e(rS+ω)t+rr+2ωerSt)+2μSF¯0ωe(rS+ω)t(e(rS+ω)t−erSt)+O(μ2),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \overline{F^{2}}(t) = & \, \overline{F^{2}}_{0}e^{2(r_{S}+\omega)t}+\overline{F}_{0}e^{(r_{S}+\omega)t}\left(e^{(r_{S}+\omega)t}-1\right) \\ & +\frac{\mu\overline{S}_{o}}{\omega}\left(\frac{2\omega}{r+2\omega}e^{2(r_{S}+\omega)t}-e^{(r_{S}+\omega)t}+\frac{r}{r+2\omega}e^{r_{S}t}\right) \\ & +\frac{2\mu\overline{SF}_{0}}{\omega}e^{(r_{S}+\omega)t}\left(e^{(r_{S}+\omega)t}-e^{r_{S}t}\right) \\ & +O(\mu^{2}), $$\end{document}

where Fo2¯≡F2¯(0)\begin{document}$\overline{F_{o}^{2}}\equiv\overline{F^{2}}(0)$\end{document} is the second moment of initial values. Thus, the variance σF2(t)=F2¯(t)−[F¯(t)]2\begin{document}$\sigma_{F}^{2}(t)=\overline{F^{2}}(t)-[\overline{F}(t)]^{2}$\end{document} is given, up to the order of μ\begin{document}$\mu$\end{document}, by(33)σF2(t)=σF,02e2(rS+ω)t+F¯0e(rS+ω)t(e(rS+ω)t−1)+μS¯oω(2ωrS+2ωe2(rS+ω)t−e(rS+ω)t+rSrS+2ωerSt)+2μ(SF¯0−S¯0F¯0)ωe(rS+ω)t(e(rS+ω)t−erSt)+O(μ2).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \sigma_F^2(t)= &\, \sigma_{F, 0}^2 e^{2\left(r_S+\omega\right) t}+\overline{F}_0 e^{\left(r_S+\omega\right) t}\left(e^{\left(r_S+\omega\right) t}-1\right) \\& +\frac{\mu \overline{S}_o}{\omega}\left(\frac{2 \omega}{r_S+2 \omega} e^{2\left(r_S+\omega\right) t}-e^{\left(r_S+\omega\right) t}+\frac{r_S}{r_S+2 \omega} e^{r_S t}\right) \\& +\frac{2 \mu\left(\overline{S F}_0-\overline{S}_0\, \overline{F}_0\right)}{\omega} e^{\left(r_S+\omega\right) t}\left(e^{\left(r_S+\omega\right) t}-e^{r_S t}\right) \\& +O\left(\mu^2\right) .$$\end{document}

Using Rτ=erSτ\begin{document}$R_{\tau}=e^{r_S\tau}$\end{document} and Wτ=eωτ\begin{document}$W_{\tau}=e^{\omega\tau}$\end{document}, we rewrite(34)σF2(t)=σF,02Rt2Wt2+F¯0RtWt(RtWt−1)+μS¯oRtω(2ωrS+2ωRtWt2−Wt+rSrS+2ω)+2μ(SF¯0−S¯0F¯0)ωRt2Wt(Wt−1)+O(μ2).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \sigma_{F}^{2}(t) = & \, \sigma_{F,0}^{2}R_{t}^{2}W_{t}^{2}+\overline{F}_{0}R_{t}W_{t}(R_{t}W_{t}-1)\\ & +\frac{\mu\overline{S}_{o}R_{t}}{\omega}\left(\frac{2\omega}{r_{S}+2\omega}R_{t}W_{t}^{2}-W_{t}+\frac{r_{S}}{r_{S}+2\omega}\right) \\ & +\frac{2\mu(\overline{SF}_{0}-\overline{S}_{0}\overline{F}_{0})}{\omega}R_{t}^{2}W_{t}(W_{t}-1) \\ & +O(\mu^{2}). $$\end{document}

Using Equations 18; 19; 28; 33, we construct pdfs for S(t)\begin{document}$S(t)$\end{document} and F(t)\begin{document}$F(t)$\end{document} at the end of cycle t=τ\begin{document}$t=\tau$\end{document}. Then, we randomly sample a number from P(S,τ)\begin{document}$P(S,\tau)$\end{document} for S(τ)\begin{document}$S(\tau)$\end{document} and another number from P(F,τ)\begin{document}$P(F,\tau)$\end{document} for F(τ)\begin{document}$F(\tau)$\end{document}. Those two numbers are cell numbers in a single Adult. We repeat this process for each Newborn to get cell numbers of all Adults. Note that the initial values for the Newborn i\begin{document}$i$\end{document} are S¯0=Sk,0(i), F¯0=Fk,0(i), σS,02=0,\begin{document}$\overline{S}_{0}=S_{k,0}^{(i)},\ \overline{F}_{0}=F_{k,0}^{(i)},\ \sigma_{S,0} ^{2}=0,$\end{document} and σF,02=0\begin{document}$\sigma_{F,0}^{2}=0$\end{document}. This process only requires two random numbers per collective, while the result is consistent with the individual-based simulation.

Now, we check the validity of the Gaussian approximation for probability density functions of S and F populations. If we consider mutation from S to F as death in the S population, then the process in S corresponds to a branching process with death. Also, the birth process in F, including mutation, results in a Luria-Delbrück distribution (Zheng, 1999). Thus, the distributions of Adults’ S and F numbers are more skewed and heavy-tailed than Gaussian. But this problem is alleviated by larger initial S and F numbers and when the maturation time τ\begin{document}$\tau$\end{document} is not very long (see Appendix 1—figure 1). Since we usually consider larger initial cell numbers, we use the Gaussian approximation on S and F populations in further calculations.

caption.title: Comparison between the calculated Gaussian distribution (‘Gauss,’ with the mean and variances computed from Equations 18; 19; 28; 33) and simulations using tau-leaping (‘tau’).
caption.p: The simulations run 3000 times. The initial number of cells are (S0,F0)=(990,10),(500,500)\begin{document}$(S_{0},F_{0})=(990,10),(500,500)$\end{document}, and (10,990)\begin{document}$(10,990)$\end{document} for each column. The parameters r=0.5\begin{document}$r=0.5$\end{document}, ω=0.03\begin{document}$\omega=0.03$\end{document}, μ=0.0001\begin{document}$\mu=0.0001$\end{document}, and τ=4.8\begin{document}$\tau=4.8$\end{document} are used.

sec.title: Selection
sec.p: After sampling cell numbers of each Adult in the maturation step, we compute the F frequencies in each collectives {fk,τ(1),⋯,fk,τ(g)}\begin{document}$\{f_{k,\tau}^{(1)},\cdots,f_{k,\tau}^{(g)}\}$\end{document}. We denote the F frequency of collective i\begin{document}$i$\end{document} at time t=τ\begin{document}$t=\tau$\end{document} in cycle k\begin{document}$k$\end{document} as fk,τ(i)\begin{document}$f_{k,\tau}^{(i)}$\end{document}. Among the g\begin{document}$g$\end{document} Adults, we select one collective with the F frequency which is the closest value to the target frequency f^\begin{document}$\hat{f}$\end{document}. The selected Adult’s F frequency value is denoted by fk∗\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*}$\end{document}. In mathematical expression, the selected frequency is defined by(35)fk∗=argminfk,τ(i),i∈{1,⋯,g}|fk,τ(i)−f^|.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle f_{k}^{*}=\mathrm{argmin}_{f_{k,\tau}^{(i)},i\in\{1,\cdots,g\}}|f_{k,\tau}^{(i)}-\hat{f}|.$$\end{document}

sec.title: Reproduction
sec.p: Using the chosen Adult, we generate g\begin{document}$g$\end{document} Newborn collectives for the next cycle k+1\begin{document}$k+1$\end{document}. The most natural way is consecutive random sampling N0\begin{document}$N_0$\end{document} cells from the selected Adult without replacement. In the mathematical expression, we first randomly sample Fk+1,0(1)\begin{document}$F_{k+1,0}^{(1)}$\end{document} F cells and draw Sk+1,0(1)=N0−Fk+1,0(1)\begin{document}$S_{k+1,0}^{(1)}=N_{0}-F_{k+1,0}^{(1)}$\end{document} S cells from the selected Adult. Next, we sample Fk+1,0(2)\begin{document}$F_{k+1,0}^{(2)}$\end{document} F cells and Sk+1,0(2)=N0−Fk+1,0(2)\begin{document}$S_{k+1,0}^{(2)}=N_{0}-F_{k+1,0}^{(2)}$\end{document} S cells from the remaining cells in the Adult. We repeat the process g\begin{document}$g$\end{document} times. Then the jpdf to choose Fk+1,0(1),⋯,Fk+1,0(g)\begin{document}$F_{k+1,0}^{(1)},\cdots,F_{k+1,0}^{(g)}$\end{document} F cells, P(Fk+1,0(1),⋯,Fk+1,0(g))\begin{document}$P(F_{k+1,0}^{(1)},\cdots,F_{k+1,0}^{(g)})$\end{document}, follows a multivariate hypergeometric distribution.

If we assume that the selected Adult size Nk∗=Sk∗+Fk∗\begin{document}$N_{k}^{*}=S_{k}^{*}+F_{k}^{*}$\end{document} is large enough compared to Newborn size N0\begin{document}$N_{0}$\end{document}, the consecutive sampling is well approximated to the independent binomial sampling (see Appendix 1—figure 2). Thus, we independently sample g\begin{document}$g$\end{document} numbers of F cells, {Fk+1,0(1),⋯,Fk+1,0(g)}\begin{document}$\{F_{k+1,0}^{(1)},\cdots,F_{k+1,0}^{(g)}\}$\end{document}, from the binomial distribution. The probability mass function of each Fk+1,0(i)\begin{document}$F_{k+1,0}^{(i)}$\end{document} is given by(36)PFk+1,0(i)(F)=N0!(N0−F)!F!(fk∗)F(1−fk∗)N0−F.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle P_{F_{k+1,0}^{(i)}}(F)=\frac{N_{\mathrm{0}}!}{(N_{0}-F)!F!}(f_{k}^{*})^{F}(1-f_{k}^{*})^{N_{0}-F}.$$\end{document}

After sampling, the numbers of S cells are set to be Sk+1(i)(0)=N0−Fk+1,0(i)\begin{document}$S_{k+1}^{(i)}(0)=N_{0}-F_{k+1,0}^{(i)}$\end{document} for each collective. We can now start cycle k+1\begin{document}$k+1$\end{document} with these Newborn collectives. By repeating the above three steps (maturation, selection, and reproduction), we run the simulation until F frequency reaches a stationary state.

caption.title: Congruence between consecutive sampling (MHG for multivariate hypergeometric distribution) and independent binomial (BN) sampling.
caption.p: The initial number of cells are S=8000\begin{document}$S=8000$\end{document} and F=2000\begin{document}$F=2000$\end{document} for the left panel, and S=20\begin{document}$S=20$\end{document} and F=5\begin{document}$F=5$\end{document} for the right panel. 10,000 samples are drawn for each distribution. Here, a parent collective is divided into 10 collectives.

sec.title: Simulation result
sec.p: Appendix 1—figure 3 presents the composition trajectories of all collectives using the tau-leaping algorithm in the maturation step. The selected adults have the closest composition to the target composition f^\begin{document}$\hat{f}$\end{document}. The selected Adult can have smaller F frequency than its parent Adult, so F frequency can be lowered after cycles.

caption.title: Trajectories of F frequency for 10 collectives (g=10\begin{document}$g=10$\end{document}) over time.
caption.p: (a) The collective whose frequency is closest to the target value is selected in every cycle (black lines). The gray lines denote the other collectives. For parameters, we used S growth rate rS=0.5\begin{document}$r_{S}=0.5$\end{document}, F growth advantage ω=0.03\begin{document}$\omega=0.03$\end{document}, mutation rate μ=0.0001\begin{document}$\mu=0.0001$\end{document}, maturation time τ≈4.8\begin{document}$\tau\approx 4.8$\end{document}, and N0=1000\begin{document}$N_{0}=1000$\end{document}. (b) Comparison between frequency trajectories with selection (the chosen one Adult producing all offspring; black) and without selection (each Adult producing one offspring; blue) clearly shows the effect of artificial selection. The black line indicates F frequency of the selected collective fk∗\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*}$\end{document} at each cycle in (a). The blue line indicates the average trajectory without selection fk+1∗\begin{document}$f_{k+1}^{*}$\end{document} (the average of g=10\begin{document}$g=10$\end{document} individual lineages without inter-collective selection at the end of each cycle).

sec.p: In Appendix 1—figure 4, we plot the absolute error d\begin{document}$d$\end{document} between the target frequency f^\begin{document}$\hat{f}$\end{document} and ⟨f∗⟩\begin{document}$\langle f^{*}\rangle$\end{document} (i.e. d=|⟨f∗⟩−f^|\begin{document}$d=|\langle f^{*}\rangle-\hat{f}|$\end{document}) at the end of simulations (1000 cycles). Since the computing time for the Tau-leaping algorithm (individual-based simulation) to reach 1000 cycles is very long, we used the sampling scheme in the above subsection. In the colormap, errors higher than 0.15 are marked with gray, which indicates selection failure. The dashed lines indicate the same boundary in Figure 2e in the main text.

caption.title: Color map of the absolute error d=|⟨f∗⟩−f^|\begin{document}$d=|\langle f^{*}\rangle-\hat{f}|$\end{document} averaged selected collectives at the end of simulations (k=1000\begin{document}$k=1000$\end{document}) and the target frequency f^\begin{document}$\hat{f}$\end{document}.
caption.p: The solid and dashed lines are drawn by the arguments in the main text. For parameters, we used rS=0.5\begin{document}$r_{S}=0.5$\end{document}, ω=0.03\begin{document}$\omega=0.03$\end{document}, μ=0.0001, N0=1000, g=10\begin{document}$\mu=0.0001,\ N_{0}=1000,\ g=10$\end{document} and τ≈4.8\begin{document}$\tau\approx 4.8$\end{document}. The result is the average of 300 independent simulations. Compared to Figure 2e, this figure has a higher resolution.

sec.title: Conditional probability distribution of the selected collective frequency f∗\begin{document}$f^{*}$\end{document} and selection progress Δf\begin{document}$\Delta f$\end{document}
sec.p: In the main text, we identify the region of success by using selection progress Δf=Median[Ψ(fk+1∗|fk∗)]−fk∗\begin{document}$\Delta f=\text{Median}[\Psi(f_{k+1}^{*}|f_{k}^{*})]-f_{k}^{*}$\end{document}, which is obtained from the conditional pdf of fk+1∗\begin{document}$f_{k+1}^*$\end{document} (the F frequency of the selected Adult at cycle k+1\begin{document}$k+1$\end{document}) given the selected fk∗\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*}$\end{document} at cycle k\begin{document}$k$\end{document}, written as Ψ(fk+1∗=f|fk∗)\begin{document}$\Psi(f_{k+1}^{*}=\!f|f_{k}^{*})$\end{document}. We consider the challenging case where fk∗\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*}$\end{document} is above the target value (fk∗>f^\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*} \gt \hat{f}$\end{document}), and therefore the Adult with minimum F frequency will be selected. To get an analytical expression of Ψ(fk+1∗=f|fk∗)\begin{document}$\Psi(f_{k+1}^{*}=f|f_{k}^{*})$\end{document}, we first find the conditional pdf of f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} of Adults in cycle k+1\begin{document}$k+1$\end{document} given fk∗\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*}$\end{document} at cycle k\begin{document}$k$\end{document}. Then, we find Ψ(fk+1∗|fk∗)\begin{document}$\Psi(f_{k+1}^{*}|f_{k}^{*})$\end{document} from the minimum value distribution of F frequencies among GS(τ)\begin{document}$G_{S}(\tau)$\end{document} Adults. Below, we describe the mathematical details of this process.

Let us start from the reproduction step from the selected Adult in cycle k\begin{document}$k$\end{document}. We reproduce g\begin{document}$g$\end{document} Newborns in the next cycle k+1.\begin{document}$k+1.$\end{document} Then the probability distribution of the F cell numbers in Newborn collectives is given in Equation 36. If the total number of cells in a Newborn collective N0\begin{document}$N_{0}$\end{document} is large enough, Equation 36 is approximated by the Gaussian distribution Fk+1,0(i)∼N(N0fk∗,N0fk∗(1−fk∗))\begin{document}$F_{k+1,0}^{(i)}\sim\mathcal{N}(N_{0}f_{k}^{*},N_{0}f_{k}^{*}(1-f_{k}^{*}))$\end{document}. Then, the probability density function that fk+1,0(i)\begin{document}$f_{k+1,0}^{(i)}$\end{document} to be ζ\begin{document}$\zeta$\end{document} in Newborn collective i\begin{document}$i$\end{document} is(37)Pfk+1,0(i)(ζ|fk∗)=N02πfk∗(1−fk∗)e−N0(ζ−fk∗)22fk∗(1−fk∗).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle P_{f_{k+1,0}^{\, (i)}}(\zeta|f_{k}^{*})=\frac{\sqrt{N_{0}}}{\sqrt{2\pi f_{k}^{*}(1-f_{k}^{*})}}e^{-\frac{N_{0}(\zeta-f_{k}^{*})^{2}}{2f_{k}^{*}(1-f_{k}^{*})}}.$$\end{document}

The Newborn collective i\begin{document}$i$\end{document} has initial cell numbers Sk+1,0(i)=N0(1−ζ)\begin{document}$S_{k+1,0}^{(i)}=N_{0}(1-\zeta)$\end{document} and Fk+1,0(i)=N0ζ\begin{document}$F_{k+1,0}^{(i)}=N_{0}\zeta$\end{document}. From here, we ignore cycle index k+1\begin{document}$k+1$\end{document} in subscript and i\begin{document}$i$\end{document} superscript for convenience.

Next, we write the conditional pdf of Adults’ F frequency with given Newborn F frequency ζ\begin{document}$\zeta$\end{document}. We assume that cell numbers in Adult S(τ)\begin{document}$S(\tau)$\end{document} and F(τ)\begin{document}$F(\tau)$\end{document} follow Gaussian distributions as in Equations 13; 14. Based on Equations 18; 19; 28; 33, we have(38)S(τ)≈S¯(τ)+σS(τ)GS(τ),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle S(\tau)\approx\overline{S}(\tau)+\sigma_{S}(\tau)G_{S}(\tau),$$\end{document}(39)F(τ)≈F¯(τ)+σF(τ)GF(τ),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle F(\tau)\approx\overline{F}(\tau)+\sigma_{F}(\tau)G_{F}(\tau),$$\end{document}

where GS(τ)\begin{document}$G_S(\tau)$\end{document} and GF(τ)\begin{document}$G_{F}(\tau)$\end{document} are random variables following the standard distribution N(0,1)\begin{document}$\mathcal{N}(0,1)$\end{document}. Note that each Gaussian is sharp if Newborn size N0\begin{document}$N_{0}$\end{document} is sufficiently large (S¯(τ)≫σs(τ)\begin{document}$\overline{S}(\tau)\gg\sigma_s(\tau)$\end{document} and F¯(τ)≫σF(τ)\begin{document}$\overline{F}(\tau)\gg\sigma_F(\tau)$\end{document}). Then, we can approximately write f(τ)\begin{document}$f(\tau )$\end{document} as(40)f(τ)≈F¯(τ)+σF(τ)GF(τ)S¯(τ)+σS(t)GS(τ)+F¯(τ)+σF(τ)GF(τ)≈f¯(τ)+σf(t)Gf(τ).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle f(\tau) & \approx \frac{\overline{F}(\tau)+\sigma_{F}(\tau)G_{F}(\tau)}{\overline{S }(\tau)+\sigma_{S}(t)G_{S}(\tau)+\overline{F}(\tau)+\sigma_{F}(\tau)G_{F}(\tau)}\\ & \approx \overline{f}(\tau)+\sigma_{f}(t)G_{f}(\tau)\end {aligned}.$$\end{document}

The mean of f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} is given by(41)f¯(τ)=F¯(τ)S¯(τ)+F¯(τ)=ζWτ+μω(1−ζ)(Wτ−1)1−ζ+ζWτ+μω(1−ζ)(Wτ−1),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \overline{f}(\tau)=\frac{\overline{F}(\tau)}{\overline{S}(\tau)+\overline{F}(\tau)}=\frac{\zeta W_{\tau}+\frac{\mu}{\omega}(1-\zeta)(W_{\tau}-1)}{1-\zeta+ \zeta W_{\tau}+\frac{\mu}{\omega}(1-\zeta)(W_{\tau}-1)},$$\end{document}

and the variance is(42)σf2(τ)=(1−f¯(τ))2σF2(τ)+f¯(τ)2σS2(τ)N¯(τ)2=1N0Rτ((1−ζ)+ζWτ+μω(1−ζ)(Wτ−1))4×[(1−ζ)2(ζWτ(RτWτ−1)+μω(1−ζ)(2ω/rS1+2ω/rSRτWτ2−Wτ+11+2ω/rS))+(ζWτ+μω(1−ζ)(Wτ−1))2(1−ζ)(Rτ−1)].\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \sigma^2_{f}(\tau) =& \, \frac{(1-\overline{f}(\tau))^{2}\sigma_{F}^{2}(\tau)+\overline{f} (\tau)^{2}\sigma_{S}^{2}(\tau)}{\overline{N}(\tau)^{2}} \\ = & \, \frac{1}{N_{0}R_{\tau}\left((1-\zeta)+\zeta W_{\tau}+\frac{\mu}{\omega}(1-\zeta)(W_{\tau}-1)\right)^{4}}\times \\ & \bigg[\left(1-\zeta\right)^{2}\left(\zeta W_{\tau}(R_{\tau}W_{\tau}-1)+\frac{\mu}{\omega}(1-\zeta)\left(\frac{2\omega/r_{S}}{1+2\omega/r_{S}}R_{\tau}W_{\tau}^{2}-W_{\tau}+\frac{1}{1+2\omega/r_{S}}\right)\right) \\ & +\left(\zeta W_{\tau}+\frac{\mu}{\omega}(1-\zeta)(W_{\tau}-1)\right)^{2}(1-\zeta)(R_{\tau}-1)\bigg].\end {aligned}$$\end{document}

where Rτ=erSτ\begin{document}$R_{\tau}=e^{r_{S}\tau}$\end{document} and Wτ=eωτ\begin{document}$W_{\tau}=e^{\omega\tau}$\end{document}. The average Adult size is N¯(τ)=S¯(τ)+F¯(τ)\begin{document}$\overline{N}(\tau)=\overline{S}(\tau)+\overline{F}(\tau)$\end{document}. Thus, the Adult’s F frequency f(τ)=fτ\begin{document}$f(\tau)=f_{\tau}$\end{document} follows the Gaussian distribution N(f¯τ,σfτ2)\begin{document}$\mathcal{N}(\overline{f}_\tau,\sigma^2_{f_\tau})$\end{document} whose pdf is given by(43)Pfτ(f|ζ)=12πσfτe−(f−fτ¯)22σfτ2.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle P_{f_{\tau}}(f|\zeta)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}\sigma_{f_{\tau}}}e^{-\frac{(f-\overline{f_{\tau}})^{2}}{2\sigma_{f_{\tau}}^{2}}}.$$\end{document}

Next, we get the conditional pdf of fk+1,τ\begin{document}$f_{k+1,\tau}$\end{document} (offspring Adult’s F frequency in cycle k+1\begin{document}$k+1$\end{document}) given fk∗\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*}$\end{document} . We multiply Equations 37 and 43 and take the integral over ζ\begin{document}$\zeta$\end{document}:(44)Pfk+1,τ(f|fk∗)=∫01dζ Pfk+1,τ(f|ζ) Pfk+1,0(ζ|fk∗).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle P_{f_{k+1,\tau}}(f|f_{k}^{*})=\int_{0}^{1}d\zeta\ P_{f_{k+1,\tau}}(f|\zeta)\ P_{f_{k+1,0}}(\zeta|f_{k}^{*}). $$\end{document}

After maturation in cycle k+1\begin{document}$k+1$\end{document}, the Adult with the smallest frequency is selected among g\begin{document}$g$\end{document} Adult collectives, denoted as fk+1min\begin{document}$f_{\text{k+1}}^{\text{min}}$\end{document} . The pdf of fk+1min\begin{document}$f_{k+1}^{\mathrm{min}}$\end{document} is obtained by the theory of extreme value statistics (Gumbel, 1958). The cumulative distribution function (cdf) of the minimum value fk+1min\begin{document}$f^{\text{min}}_{k+1}$\end{document} is given by(45)Cfk+1min(f|fk∗)=Prob[fk+1min≤f|fk∗] =1−Prob[fk+1,τmin≥f|fk∗]=1−Prob[(fk+1,τ(1)≥f)∧(fk+1,τ(2)≥f)∧⋯∧(fk+1,τ(g)≥f)|fk∗].\begin{document}$$\displaystyle C_{f_{k+1}^{\, \min}}(f|f_{k}^{*}) &= \mathrm{Prob} \left[f_{k+1}^{\, \min}\leq f|f_{k}^{*} \right]\ \\ & = 1-\mathrm{Prob} \left[f_{k+1,\tau}^{\, \min}\geq f|f_{k}^{*} \right] \\ & = 1-\mathrm{Prob} \left[(f_{k+1,\tau}^{(1)}\geq f)\wedge(f_{k+1,\tau}^{(2)}\geq f)\wedge\cdots\wedge(f_{k+1,\tau}^{(g)}\geq f)|f_{k}^{*} \right]. $$\end{document}

Since frequencies are independent and identically distributed, Cfk+1min(f|fk∗)=1−[Prob(fk+1,τ≥f)|fk∗]g\begin{document}$C_{f_{\text{k+1}}^{\mathrm{min}}}(f|f_{k}^{*})=\mathrm{1-[Prob}(f_{k+1,\tau} \geq f)|f_{k}^{*}]^{g}$\end{document}. Note that Prob[fk+1,τ≥f|fk∗]\begin{document}$\text{Prob}[f_{k+1,\tau}\geq f|f_{k}^{*}]$\end{document} =∫f1df′Pfk+1,τ(f′|fk∗)\begin{document}$=\int_{f}^{1}df^{\prime}P_{f_{k+1, \tau}}(f^{\prime}|f_{k}^{*})$\end{document} =1−∫0fdf′Pfk+1,τ(f′|fk∗)\begin{document}$=1-\int_{0}^{f}df^{\prime}P_{f_{k+1,\tau}}(f^{ \prime}|f_{k}^{*})$\end{document} =1−Cfk+1,τ(f|fk∗)\begin{document}$=1-C_{f_{k+1,\tau}}(f|f_{k}^{*})$\end{document} , and Equation 45 becomes(46)Cfk+1min(f|fk∗)=1−(1−Cfk+1,τ(f|fk∗))g.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle C_{f_{k+1}^{\mathrm{min}}}(f|f_{k}^{*})=1-\left(1-C_{f_{k+1,\tau}}(f|f_{k}^{*})\right)^{g}.$$\end{document}

Then, the probability density function Ψ(fk+1∗|fk∗)\begin{document}$\Psi(f_{k+1}^{*}|f_{k}^{*})$\end{document} is obtained by differentiating Equation 46 with respect to f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} and replacing f⟶fk+1∗\begin{document}$f\longrightarrow f^*_{k+1}$\end{document},(47)Ψ(fk+1∗|fk∗)=g(1−Cfk+1,τ(fk+1∗|fk∗))g−1Pfk+1,τ(fk+1∗|fk∗).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \Psi(f_{k+1}^{*}|f_{k}^{*})=g\left(1-C_{f_{k+1,\tau}}(f_{k+1}^{*}|f_{k}^{*})\right)^{g-1}P_{f_{k+1,\tau}}(f_{k+1}^{*}|f_{k}^{*}).$$\end{document}
We compute the probability density function Equation 47 by using numerical integration and compare it with the stochastic simulation results in Appendix 2—figure 1. The two distributions are similar.

To get the analytic approximation of the median of Equation 47, we assume that the Adult’s F frequency distribution is Gaussian. Then we only need to calculate the mean f¯(τ)\begin{document}$\overline{f}(\tau)$\end{document} and variance σf2(τ)\begin{document}$\sigma_{f}^{2}(\tau)$\end{document} of Adult’s F frequency. Instead of calculating the integral with respect to ζ\begin{document}$\zeta$\end{document} in Equation 44, we put a set of initial values from Newborn’s F frequency distribution N(fk∗,fk∗(1−fk∗)/N0)\begin{document}$\mathcal{N}(f^*_{k},f^*_{k}(1-f^*_{k})/N_0) $\end{document} in Equations 20, 21, 28 and 34: S¯0=N0(1−fk∗)\begin{document}$\overline{S}_{0}=N_{0}(1-f_{k}^{*})$\end{document}, F¯0=N0fk∗\begin{document}$ \overline{F}_{0}=N_{0}f_{k}^{*}$\end{document}, σS,02=N0fk∗(1−fk∗)\begin{document}$\sigma_{S,0}^{2}=N_{0}f_{k}^{*}(1-f_{k}^{*})$\end{document}, σF,02=N0fk∗(1−fk∗)\begin{document}$\sigma^2_{F,0} = N_0 f^*_k(1- f^*_k)$\end{document}, and SF¯0−S¯0F¯0=−N0fk∗(1−fk∗)\begin{document}$\overline{SF}_{0}-\overline{S}_{0}\overline{F}_{0}=-N_{0}f_{k}^{*}(1-f_{k}^{*})$\end{document}. Then we have(48)f¯(τ)=F¯(τ)S¯(τ)+F¯(τ)=fk∗Wτ+μω(1−fk∗)(Wτ−1)1−fk∗+fk∗Wτ+μω(1−fk∗)(Wτ−1),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \overline{f}(\tau)=\frac{\overline{F}(\tau)}{\overline{S}(\tau)+\overline{F}(\tau)}=\frac{f_{k}^{*}W_{\tau}+\frac{\mu}{\omega}(1-f_{k}^{*})(W_{\tau}-1)}{1- f_{k}^{*}+f_{k}^{*}W_{\tau}+\frac{\mu}{\omega}(1-f_{k}^{*})(W_{\tau}-1)},$$\end{document}(49)σf2(τ)=(1−fk∗)N0Rτ(1−fk∗+fk∗Wτ+μω(1−fk∗)(Wτ−1))4×[fk∗Wτ{(2−2fk∗+2fk∗2)RτWτ−(1−fk∗)−fk∗Wτ}+μω(1−fk∗){(1−fk∗)((2ωrS+2ω−2fk∗)RτWτ2−Wt+rSrS+2ω+2fk∗RτWτ)+2fk∗((1+fk∗)Rτ−1)Wτ(Wτ−1)}+O(μ2)],\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \sigma_{f}^{2}(\tau) = & \, \frac{(1-f_{k}^{*})}{N_{0}R_{\tau}\left(1-f_{k}^{*}+f_{k}^{*}W_{\tau}+\frac{\mu}{\omega}(1-f_{k}^{*})(W_{\tau}-1)\right)^{4}}\times \\ & \bigg[f_{k}^{*}W_{\tau}\left\{ (2-2f_{k}^{*}+2f_{k}^{*2})R_{\tau}W_{\tau}-(1-f_{k}^{*})-f_{k}^{*}W_{\tau}\right\} \\ & +\frac{\mu}{\omega}(1-f_{k}^{*})\biggl\{(1-f_{k}^{*})\biggl(\left(\frac{2\omega}{r_{S}+2\omega}-2f_{k}^{*}\right)R_{\tau}W_{\tau}^{2}-W_{t}+\frac{r_{S}}{r_{S}+2\omega}+2f_{k}^{*}R_{\tau}W_{\tau}\biggr)\\& +2f_{k}^{*}\bigl((1+f_{k}^{*})R_{\tau}-1\bigr)W_{\tau}(W_{\tau}-1)\biggr\}+O(\mu^{2}) \bigg],\end {aligned}$$\end{document}
which give rise to Equation 3 and Equation 4 in the main text, respectively. The functional form of Equations 48; 49 are plotted in Appendix 2—figure 2a.

The median (Median[Ψ(fk+1∗|fk∗)]≡f~\begin{document}$\text{Median}[\Psi(f_{k+1}^{*}|f_{k}^{*})]\equiv\tilde{f}$\end{document}) of Equation 47 satisfies Cfk+1min(f~|fk∗)=12\begin{document}$C_{f_{k+1}^{\mathrm{min}}}(\tilde{f}|f_{k}^{*})=\frac{1}{2}$\end{document}, which means f~=Cfk+1,τ−1(ln⁡2g)\begin{document}$\tilde{f}=C_{f_{k+1,\tau}}^{-1}\left(\frac{\ln 2}{g}\right)$\end{document}. If we assume that the distribution Equation 47 is Gaussian, then the inverse function Cfk+1,τ−1(ln⁡2g)\begin{document}$C_{f_{k+1,\tau}}^{-1}\left(\frac{\ln 2}{g}\right)$\end{document} can be written as(50)Median[Ψ(fk+1∗|fk∗)]=Cfk+1,τ−1(ln⁡2g)=f¯(τ)+[Φ−1(ln⁡2g)]σf(τ),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \text{Median}[\Psi(f_{k+1}^{*}|f_{k}^{*})]=C_{f_{k+1,\tau}}^{-1}\left(\frac{\ln2}{g}\right)=\overline{f}(\tau)+\left[\Phi^{-1}\left(\frac{\ln2}{g}\right)\right]\sigma_{f}(\tau),$$\end{document}

where Φ−1(y)\begin{document}$\Phi^{-1}(y)$\end{document} is an inverse cumulative density function (CDF) of the normal distribution with mean i\begin{document}$i$\end{document} in Equation 49 and standard deviation σf(τ)\begin{document}$\sigma_{f}(\tau)$\end{document}, a square root of Equation 49. Subtracting fk∗\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*}$\end{document} from Equation 50 gives the selection progress(51)Δf=Median[Ψ(fk+1∗|fk∗)]−fk∗=f¯(τ)+[Φ−1(ln⁡2g)]σf(τ)−fk∗\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \Delta f=\text{Median}[\Psi(f_{k+1}^{*}|f_{k}^{*})]-f_{k}^{*}=\overline{f}(\tau)+\left[\Phi^{-1}\left(\frac{\ln2}{g}\right)\right]\sigma_{f}(\tau)-f_{k}^{*}$$\end{document}
which is Equation 2 in the main text.

Furthermore, we get an asymptotic expression of Φ−1(ln⁡2/g)\begin{document}$\Phi^{-1}(\ln 2/g)$\end{document} when g\begin{document}$g$\end{document} is large (or Φ−1(y)\begin{document}$\Phi^{-1}(y)$\end{document} with small y\begin{document}$y$\end{document}). Here, we introduce a method from Phllip, 1960. We start from the CDF of the standard normal distribution, Φ(x)=erfc(−x/2)/2\begin{document}$\Phi(x)=\text{erfc}(-x/\sqrt{2})/2$\end{document} where the function x\begin{document}$x$\end{document} is the complementary error function. To get the expression of Φ−1\begin{document}$\Phi^{-1}$\end{document}, we need an asymptotic expression of the inverse of y=erfc(x)\begin{document}$y=\text{erfc(x)}$\end{document} function (x=erfc−1(y)\begin{document}$x=\text{erfc}^{-1}(y)$\end{document}) as the inverse CDF Φ−1(y)=−2erfc−1(2y)\begin{document}$\Phi^{-1}(y)=-\sqrt{2}\text{erfc}^{-1}(2y)$\end{document}. The known asymptotic expansion of y=erfc(x)\begin{document}$y=\text{erfc}(x)$\end{document} for large Φ−1(ln⁡2/g)\begin{document}$\Phi^{-1}(\ln 2/g)$\end{document} is erfc(x)≈e−x2/xπ\begin{document}$\text{erfc}(x)\approx e^{-x^{2}}/x\sqrt{\pi}$\end{document}. By taking the logarithm of both sides, we have(52)x2≈−ln⁡y−12ln⁡πx2.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle x^{2}\approx-\ln y-\frac{1}{2}\ln\pi x^{2}.$$\end{document}

Replacing x2\begin{document}$x^{2}$\end{document} on the right-hand side in Equation 52 into the expression itself, we get a continued logarithmic form of(53)x2≈−ln⁡y−12ln⁡π(−ln⁡y−12ln⁡π(−ln⁡y−12ln⁡⋯).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle x^{2}\approx-\ln y-\frac{1}{2}\ln\pi(-\ln y-\frac{1}{2}\ln\pi(-\ln y-\frac{1}{2}\ln\cdots).$$\end{document}

Inserting x=erfc−1(y)\begin{document}$x=\text{erfc}^{-1}(y)$\end{document} (square root of Equation 53) into the inverse CDF Φ−1(y)=−2erfc−1(2y)\begin{document}$\Phi^{-1}(y)=-\sqrt{2}\text{erfc}^{-1}(2y)$\end{document}, we have Φ−1(y)≈−−2ln⁡2y−lnπ(−ln⁡2y−⋯)\begin{document}$\Phi^{-1}(y)\approx-\sqrt{-2\ln 2y-\text{$\ln $$\pi(-\ln 2y-$}\cdots)}$\end{document}. So, the asymptotic expression of N(fk∗,fk∗(1−fk∗)/N0)\begin{document}$\mathcal{N}(f_{k}^{*},f_{k}^{*}(1-f_{k}^{*})/N_{0})$\end{document} is given by(54)Φ−1(ln⁡2g)≈−2ln⁡g−ln⁡[ln⁡g]+⋯.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \Phi^{-1}\left(\frac{\ln2}{g}\right)\approx-\sqrt{2\ln g-\ln[\ln g]+\cdots}. $$\end{document}

caption.title: The probability density functions of the selected Adult’s F frequency fk+1∗\begin{document}$f_{k+1}^{*}$\end{document} subtracted by fk∗\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*}$\end{document}.
caption.p: For simulations (blue), at each fk∗\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*}$\end{document}, we performed 1000 stochastic simulations. The orange distribution represents Equation 47 computed by numerical integration. The median values of the distributions are shown in Figure 3a in the main text.

caption.title: Effect of experimental parameters in the distribuiton of Adult's F frequency.
caption.p: (a) Mean (Equation 41) and variance (Equation 42) of f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} values of Adult collectives with respect to the Newborn frequency f0\begin{document}$f_{0}$\end{document}. (b) Scaling relation of F frequency variance (Equation 49) with Newborn collective size N0\begin{document}$N_{0}$\end{document}. The initial F frequency is 0.5. The parameters are rS=0.5\begin{document}$r_{S}=0.5$\end{document}, ω=0.03\begin{document}$\omega=0.03$\end{document}, μ=0.0001\begin{document}$\mu=0.0001$\end{document}, and τ≈4.8\begin{document}$\tau\approx 4.8$\end{document}. (c) Relation of F frequency variance (Equation 49) with maturation time τ\begin{document}$\tau$\end{document}. Other parameters are the same as b.

caption.title: Median (orange) and mean (violet) have similar distributions.
caption.p: We performed 1000 simulations to get probability density. (a) g=10\begin{document}$g=10$\end{document}, (b) g=100\begin{document}$g=100$\end{document}, and (c) g=1000\begin{document}$g=1000$\end{document}. Initial F frequency is fk∗=0.5\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*}=0.5$\end{document}. The parameters are rS=0.5\begin{document}$r_{S}=0.5$\end{document}, ω=0.03\begin{document}$\omega=0.03$\end{document}, μ=0.0001\begin{document}$\mu=0.0001$\end{document} and τ=ln⁡[1000]/rS\begin{document}$\tau=\ln[1000]/r_{S}$\end{document}.

sec.title: Critical newborn size N˘0\begin{document}$\breve{N}_{0}$\end{document} to allow all target frequencies
sec.p: First, we note that σf2\begin{document}$\sigma_{f}^{2}$\end{document} in Equation 49 is proportional to N0−1\begin{document}$N_{0}^{-1}$\end{document} for the following reasons. Variance σS2(t)\begin{document}$\sigma_{S}^{2}(t)$\end{document} in Equation 28 scales linearly with N0\begin{document}$N_{0}$\end{document} since both S¯0\begin{document}$\overline{S}_{0}$\end{document} and σS,02\begin{document}$\sigma_{S,0}^{2}$\end{document} scale linearly with N0\begin{document}$N_{0}$\end{document}. Variance σF2(t)\begin{document}$\sigma_{F}^{2}(t)$\end{document} in Equation 33 also scales linearly with N0\begin{document}$N_{0}$\end{document} because σF,02\begin{document}$\sigma_{F,0}^{2}$\end{document}, F¯0\begin{document}$\overline{F}_{0}$\end{document}, S¯0\begin{document}$\overline{S}_{0}$\end{document}, and covariance SF¯0−S¯0F¯0\begin{document}$\overline{SF}_{0}-\overline{S}_{0}\overline{F}_{0}$\end{document} all scale linearly with N0\begin{document}$N_{0}$\end{document}. The mean adult size N¯(τ)=S¯(τ)+F¯(τ)\begin{document}$\overline{N}(\tau)=\overline{S}(\tau)+\overline{F}(\tau)$\end{document} is also proportional to N0\begin{document}$N_{0}$\end{document} because the average cell numbers in Equations 18; 19 are linear with respect to N0\begin{document}$N_{0}$\end{document}. Thus, the scaling relation of Equation 49 is given by σf2(τ)\begin{document}$\sigma_{f}^{2}(\tau)$\end{document} =[(1−f¯(τ))2σF2(τ)+f¯(τ)2σS2(τ)]/N¯(t)2\begin{document}$=[(1-\overline{f}(\tau))^{2}\sigma_{F}^{2}(\tau)+\overline {f}(\tau)^{2}\sigma_{S}^{2}(\tau)]/\overline{N}(t)^{2}$\end{document} ∼N0/N02∼1/N0\begin{document}$\sim N_{0}/N_{0}^{2}\sim 1 /N_{0}$\end{document}.

Small N0\begin{document}$N_{0}$\end{document} makes all target frequencies achievable, as shown in Figure 4a in the main text. That is because small N0\begin{document}$N_{0}$\end{document} induces large σf\begin{document}$\sigma_{f}$\end{document}, and thus N0\begin{document}$N_{0}$\end{document} smaller than a certain critical value N˘0\begin{document}$\breve{N}_{0}$\end{document} makes the selection progress Δf\begin{document}$\Delta f$\end{document} always negative, regardless of the value of fk∗\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*}$\end{document} (i.e.Δf\begin{document}$\Delta f$\end{document} =f¯(τ)\begin{document}$=\overline{f}(\tau)$\end{document} +[Φ−1(ln⁡2g)]σf(τ)\begin{document}$+\left[\Phi^{-1}(\frac{\ln 2}{g})\right]\sigma_{f}(\tau)$\end{document} −fk∗<0\begin{document}$-f_{k}^{*} \lt 0$\end{document}). That means the inter-collective selection overcomes intra-collective selection in any target frequencies. To get an analytical approximation of the critical newborn size N˘0\begin{document}$\breve{N}_{0}$\end{document}, we simply assume that selection progress Δf\begin{document}$\Delta f$\end{document} is maximum at fk∗=1−fk∗=12\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*}=1-f_{k}^{*}=\frac{1}{2}$\end{document} where the changes in f¯\begin{document}$\overline{f}$\end{document} and σf2\begin{document}$\sigma_{f}^{2}$\end{document} are fastest. If the maximum value of Δf\begin{document}$\Delta f$\end{document} is zero, all other values of Equation 50 are negative, which naturally states that all targets are achievable. Putting fk∗=12\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*}=\frac{1}{2}$\end{document}, Equations 48; 49 become(55)f¯(τ)|fk∗=12=F¯(τ)S¯(τ)+F¯(τ)=Wτ+μω(Wτ−1)1+Wτ+μω(Wτ−1),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle {\overline{f}(\tau)|}_{f_{k}^{*}=\frac{1}{2}}=\frac{\overline{F}(\tau)}{ \overline{S}(\tau)+\overline{F}(\tau)}=\frac{W_{\tau}+\frac{\mu}{\omega}(W_{ \tau}-1)}{1+W_{\tau}+\frac{\mu}{\omega}(W_{\tau}-1)},$$\end{document}

and(56)σf2(τ)|fk∗=12≈2N0Rτ(1+Wτ+μω(Wτ−1))4×[Wτ(3RtWτ−1−Wτ)+μω{((2ωrS+2ω−1)RtWτ2−Wt+rSrS+2ω+RtWτ)+(3Rt−2)Wτ(Wτ−1)}]\begin{document}$$\displaystyle {\sigma_{f}^{2}(\tau)|}_{f_{k}^{*}=\frac{1}{2}} \approx & \, \frac{2}{N_{0}R_{\tau}\left(1+W_{\tau}+\frac{\mu}{\omega}(W_{\tau}-1)\right)^{4}}\times \\ & \bigg[W_{\tau}\left(3R_{t}W_{\tau}-1-W_{\tau}\right) \\ & +\frac{\mu}{\omega}\left\{ \left(\left(\frac{2\omega}{r_{S}+2\omega}-1\right)R_{t}W_{\tau}^{2}-W_{t}+\frac{r_{S}}{r_{S}+2\omega}+R_{t}W_{\tau}\right)+(3R_{t}-2)W_{\tau}(W_{\tau}-1)\right\} \bigg] $$\end{document}

So, by setting Δf|fk∗=12=f¯(τ)|fk∗=12+[Φ−1(ln⁡2g)]σf(τ)|fk∗=12−12=0\begin{document}$\Delta f|_{f_{k}^{*}=\frac{1}{2}}=\overline{f}(\tau)|_{f_{k}^{*}=\frac{1}{2}}+ \left[\Phi^{-1}(\frac{\ln 2}{g})\right]\sigma_{f}(\tau)|_{f_{k}^{*}=\frac{1}{2 }}-\frac{1}{2}=0$\end{document} with N0=N˘0\begin{document}$N_{0}=\breve{N}_{0}$\end{document}, we get a solution of(57)N˘0=[Φ−1(ln⁡2g)]28Rτ[1+Wτ+μω(Wτ−1)]2[1−Wτ−μω(Wτ−1)]2×[Wτ(3RτWτ−1−Wτ)+μω{((2ωrS+2ω−1)RτWτ2−Wτ+rSrS+2ω+RτWτ)+(3Rτ−2)Wτ(Wτ−1)}]\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \breve{N}_{0} = & \, \left[\Phi^{-1}\left(\frac{\ln2}{g}\right)\right]^{2}\frac{8}{R_{\tau}\left[1+W_{\tau}+\frac{\mu}{\omega}(W_{\tau}-1)\right]^{2}\left[1-W_{\tau}-\frac{\mu}{\omega}(W_{\tau}-1)\right]^{2}}\times\\ & \bigg[W_{\tau}\left(3R_{\tau}W_{\tau}-1-W_{\tau}\right) \\ & +\frac{\mu}{\omega}\left\{ \left(\left(\frac{2\omega}{r_{S}+2\omega}-1\right)R_{\tau}W_{\tau}^{2}-W_{\tau}+\frac{r_{S}}{r_{S}+2\omega}+R_{\tau}W_{\tau}\right)+(3R_{\tau}-2)W_{\tau}(W_{\tau}-1)\right\} \bigg] $$\end{document}

Thus, all target frequencies are successfully selected with Newborn size N0\begin{document}$N_{0}$\end{document} smaller than N˘0\begin{document}$\breve{N}_{0}$\end{document}. If the mutation rate is zero, the critical value becomes(58)N˘0=[Φ−1(ln⁡2g)]28Wτ(3RτWτ−Wτ−1)Rτ(Wτ2−1)2.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \breve{N}_{0}=\left[\Phi^{-1}\left(\frac{\ln2}{g}\right)\right]^{2}\frac{8W_{\tau}\left(3R_{\tau}W_{\tau}-W_{\tau}-1\right)}{R_{\tau}\left(W_{\tau}^{2}-1\right)^{2}}.$$\end{document}

sec.title: Selection without mutation μ=0\begin{document}$\mu=0$\end{document}
sec.p: When the mutation rate is zero, two genotypes behave as two distinct species. The compositional change is provided by Equation 50 with setting μ=0\begin{document}$\mu=0$\end{document}. Corresponding f¯\begin{document}$\overline{f}$\end{document} in Equation 48 and σf2\begin{document}$\sigma_{f}^{2}$\end{document} in Equation 49 become(59)f¯(τ)=fk∗Wτ1−fk∗+fk∗Wτ,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \overline{f}(\tau)=\frac{f_{k}^{*}W_{\tau}}{1-f_{k}^{*}+f_{k}^{*}W_{\tau}},$$\end{document}(60)σf2(τ)=fk∗(1−fk∗)Wτ[(2−2fk∗+2fk∗2)RτWτ−(1−fk∗)−fk∗Wτ]N0Rτ(1−fk∗+fk∗Wτ)4.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \sigma_{f}^{2}(\tau) = \frac{f_{k}^{*}(1-f_{k}^{*})W_{\tau}\left[(2-2f_{k}^{*}+2f_{k}^{*2})R_{\tau}W_{\tau}-(1-f_{k}^{*})-f_{k}^{*}W_{\tau}\right]}{N_{0}R_{\tau}\left(1-f_{k}^{*}+f_{k}^{*}W_{\tau}\right)^{4}}.$$\end{document}

Equations 59; 60 suggest that when a community consists of two competing species, we obtain similar conclusions on the accessible region for target composition. The stochastic simulation results are presented in Appendix 4—figure 1.

caption.title: Simulation with zero mutation rate.
caption.p: Color map of the absolute error d=|⟨f∗⟩−f^|\begin{document}$d=|\langle f^{*}\rangle-\hat{f}|$\end{document} between frequency ⟨f∗⟩\begin{document}$\langle f^{*}\rangle$\end{document} of the averaged selected collectives at the end of simulations (k=1000\begin{document}$k=1000$\end{document}) and the target frequency f^\begin{document}$\hat{f}$\end{document}. For parameters, we used rS=0.5\begin{document}$r_{S}=0.5$\end{document}, ω=0.03\begin{document}$\omega=0.03$\end{document}, μ=0, N0=1000, g=10\begin{document}$\mu=0,\ N_{0}=1000,\ g=10$\end{document}, and τ≈4.8\begin{document}$\tau\approx 4.8$\end{document}.

sec.title: Stronger or weaker advantages ω\begin{document}$\omega$\end{document}
sec.p: The solution of Equation (2) in main text provides the boundary values with varying the ω\begin{document}$\omega$\end{document}, the fitness advantage of F over S. We numerically calculate the solutions and plot in Appendix 5—figure 1.

caption.title: Change of success region in varying selective advantage ω.rs\begin{document}$\omega.r_s$\end{document}, ω=0.03\begin{document}$\omega=0.03$\end{document}, μ=0.0001, N0=1000, g=10\begin{document}$\mu=0.0001,\ N_{0}=1000,\ g=10$\end{document}, and τ≈4.8\begin{document}$\tau\approx 4.8$\end{document}.

sec.title: Deleterious mutation ω<0\begin{document}$\omega \lt 0$\end{document}
sec.p: In the main text, we show that the target composition can be achieved in some ranges of initial and target values when the mutation is beneficial to growth. The same analogy can be applied when the mutation is deleterious. Since the F cells grow slower than the S cells (ω<0\begin{document}$\omega \lt 0$\end{document}), the F frequency naturally decreases in the maturation step. Then, the challenging case is selecting a larger F frequency against the intra-collective selection. So the conditional probability distribution Ψ(fk+1∗|fk∗)\begin{document}$\Psi(f_{k+1}^{*}|f_{k}^{*})$\end{document} that we consider now is a maximum value distribution of Equation 44. Thus, instead of Equation 45, we look for the cumulative distribution function of the maximum value fk+1max\begin{document}$f_{k+1}^{\mathrm{max}}$\end{document} such that(61)Cfk+1max(f|fk∗)=Prob[fk+1max≥f|fk∗]=Prob[(fk+1(1)(τ)≥f)∧(fk+1(2)(τ)≥f)∧⋯∧(fk+1(g)(τ)≥f)|fk∗].\begin{document}$$\displaystyle C_{f_{k+1}^{\mathrm{max}}}(f|f_{k}^{*}) & = \mathrm{Prob}\left[f_{k+1}^{\mathrm{max}}\geq f|f_{k}^{*} \right]\nonumber \\ & = \mathrm{Prob} \left[(f_{k+1}^{(1)}(\tau)\geq f)\wedge(f_{k+1}^{(2)}(\tau)\geq f)\wedge\cdots\wedge(f_{k+1}^{(g)}(\tau)\geq f)|f_{k}^{*} \right]. $$\end{document}

If all frequencies are independent and identically distributed random variables, the cumulative distribution function becomes(62)Cfk+1max(f|fk∗)=(Cfk+1,τ(f|fk∗))g.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle C_{f_{k+1}^{\mathrm{max}}}(f|f_{k}^{*})=\left(C_{f_{k+1,\tau}}(f|f_{k}^{*})\right)^{g}.$$\end{document}

Likewise in the previous section, we get the conditional probability density function by differentiating Equation 62 with respect to f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} and replacing f→fk+1∗\begin{document}$f\rightarrow f_{k+1}^{*}$\end{document} as(63)Ψ(fk+1∗|fk∗)=g(Cfk+1,τ(fk+1∗|fk∗))g−1Pfk+1,τ(fk+1∗|fk∗).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \Psi(f_{k+1}^{*}|f_{k}^{*})=g\left(C_{f_{k+1,\tau}}(f_{k+1}^{*}|f_{k}^{*})\right)^{g-1}P_{f_{k+1,\tau}}(f_{k+1}^{*}|f_{k}^{*}).$$\end{document}

The distribution in Equation 63 is evaluated for various fk∗\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*}$\end{document} in Appendix 6—figure 1a with numerical simulations, and the median values of distributions are presented in Appendix 6—figure 1b. In the case of ω=−0.03\begin{document}$\omega=-0.03$\end{document}, the target frequency is lower than around 0.3 and larger than around 0.7 can be selected. Since the sign of ω\begin{document}$\omega$\end{document} is opposite to the result in the main text, the diagram is reversed from Figure 2e in the main text.

caption.title: Artificial selection also works for deleterious mutation.
caption.p: (a) Conditional probability density functions of fk+1∗−fk∗\begin{document}$f_{k+1}^{*}-f_{k}^{*}$\end{document} for various fk∗\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*}$\end{document} values. The left-hand side distribution is obtained from simulations and the right-hand side distribution is numerically obtained by evaluating Equation 63. Small triangles inside indicate the median values of the distributions. (b) The median value of distributions at a given fk∗\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*}$\end{document}. The points where the shifted median becomes zero, Median[Ψ(fk+1∗−fk∗|fk∗)]=0\begin{document}$\mathrm{Median}[\Psi(f_{k+1}^{*}-f_{k}^{*}|f_{k}^{*})]=0$\end{document} are denoted as fL\begin{document}$f^{L}$\end{document} and fU\begin{document}$f^{U}$\end{document}, respectively. (c) The relative error between the target frequency f^\begin{document}$\hat{f}$\end{document} and the ensemble averaged selected frequency ⟨fk∗⟩\begin{document}$\langle f_{k}^{*}\rangle$\end{document} is measured after 1000 cycles starting from the initial frequency f¯1,0\begin{document}$\overline{f}_{1,0}$\end{document}. Either the lower target frequencies or the higher target frequencies starting from the high initial frequencies can be achieved. The black dashed lines indicate the predicted boundary values fU\begin{document}$f^{U}$\end{document} and fL\begin{document}$f^{L}$\end{document} in a.

sec.title: Selecting more than one collective
sec.p: In the main text, we choose one collective which has the closest frequency to the target among g\begin{document}$g$\end{document} collectives. Such a ‘top 1’ strategy allows us to apply extreme value theory. However, ‘top 1’ may be too restrictive (Xie et al., 2019). Thus, we test the ‘top-tier’ strategy by choosing the top five among 100 Adults (Appendix 7—figure 1). The top-tier strategy is shown to be inefficient in our system. This is because in Xie et al., 2019, nonheritable variations – such as stochastic fluctuations in species composition introduced by pipetting – caused nonheritable variations in collective function. Nonheritable variations could potentially mask desired mutations if these mutations happened to occur in an ‘unlucky’ environment that yielded lower collective functions. Hence, lenient selection would allow the preservation of these mutations. In contrast here, stochastic fluctuations in genotype composition are heritable: a parent Newborn with lower F frequency f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} will tend to have offspring Newborns with lower f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} values. Hence, top-1 is more effective in this study.

caption.title: Selecting top 5% outperforms selecting top 1.
caption.p: We bred 100 collectives and chose either top-1 collective (solid line) or top-5 collectives (dashed line) with f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} closest to the target value f^\begin{document}$\widehat{f}$\end{document} (black dotted line).

sec.title: Extension to three-population system
sec.p: We assume that collectives consist of three genotypes with slow-growing (S), fast-growing (F), and faster-growing (FF) types. The growth rate of S is rS\begin{document}$r_{S}$\end{document}. Each mutation adds ω\begin{document}$\omega$\end{document} to the growth rate. Thus, the F and FF types have growth rates rS+ω\begin{document}$r_{S}+\omega$\end{document} and rS+2ω\begin{document}$r_{S}+2\omega$\end{document}, respectively. The mutation rate is μ\begin{document}$\mu$\end{document}. So, the birth and mutation events are written by the chemical reactions:(64)S→rSS+S,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \text{S} \xrightarrow{r_{S}} \text{S}+\text{S},$$\end{document}(65)F→ω>0rS+ωF+F,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \text{F} \xrightarrow[\omega \gt 0]{r_{S}+\omega} \text{F}+\text{F},$$\end{document}(66)FF→ω>0rS+2ωFF+FF,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \text{FF} \xrightarrow[\omega \gt 0]{r_{S}+2\omega} \text{FF}+\text{FF},$$\end{document}(67)S→μF,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \text{S} \xrightarrow{\mu} \text{F}, $$\end{document}(68)F→μFF\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \text{F} \xrightarrow{\mu} \text{FF}$$\end{document}

We write a master equation of the processes for P(S,F,FF,t) egin{document}$P(S,F,F
egmedspace F,t)$\end{document} which is the probability to have S egin{document}$S$\end{document}, F egin{document}$F$\end{document}, and FF egin{document}$F

egmedspace F,t)}{dt}= & \, r_{S}(S-1)P(S-1,F,F F,t)-r_{S}SP(S,F,F F ,t)\ & +(r_{S}+\omega)(F-1)P(S,F-1,F F,t)-(r_{S}+\omega)F\,P(S ,F,F F,t) \& +(r_{S}+2\omega)(F F-1)P(S,F,FF-1,t)-(r_ {S}+2\omega)FF\,P(S,F,F F,t) \ & +\mu(S+1)P(S+1,F-1,F F,t)-\mu S\,P(S,F,F F ,t) \ & +\mu(F+1)P(S,F+1,F F-1,t)-\mu F\,P(S,F,FF ,t).$$\end{document}

The composition of collective i\begin{document}$i$\end{document} in cycle k\begin{document}$k$\end{document} is now represented with two frequencies (fk(i)(t),hk(i)(t))≡pk(i)(t)\begin{document}$(f_{k}^{(i)}(t),h_{k}^{(i)}(t))\equiv\mathbf{p}_{k}^{(i)}(t)$\end{document} where the F frequency is fk(i)(t)=Fk(i)(t)/(Sk(i)(t)+Fk(i)(t)+FFk(i)(t))\begin{document}$f_{k}^{(i)}(t)=F_{k}^{(i)}(t)/(S_{k}^{(i)}(t)+F_{k}^{(i)}(t)+F\negmedspace F_{ k}^{(i)}(t))$\end{document} and the FF frequency is hk(i)(t)=FFk(i)(t)/(Sk(i)(t)+Fk(i)(t)+FFk(i)(t))\begin{document}$h_{k}^{(i)}(t)=F F_{k}^{(i)}(t)/(S_{k}^{(i)}(t)+F_{k}^{(i)}(t)+F F_{k}^{(i)}(t))$\end{document}. Then, the target composition is set to be (f^,h^)\begin{document}$(\hat{f},\hat{h})$\end{document}. The composition of the selected Adult in cycle k\begin{document}$k$\end{document} is (fk∗,hk∗)≡pk∗\begin{document}$(f_{k}^{*},h_{k}^{*})\equiv\mathbf{p}_{k}^{*}$\end{document}. We apply the processes used in the above Appendix 2 to obtain the conditional probability Ψ(pk+1∗|pk∗)\begin{document}$\Psi(\mathbf{p}_{k+1}^{*}|\mathbf{p}_{k}^{*})$\end{document} by using the master Equation 69.

At the reproduction step in cycle k\begin{document}$k$\end{document}, we choose N0\begin{document}$N_{0}$\end{document} cells from the selected Adult whose composition is (fk∗\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*}$\end{document},hk∗\begin{document}$h_{k}^{*}$\end{document})≡pk∗\begin{document}$\equiv\mathbf{p}_{k}^{*}$\end{document}. Then, newborn collectives are independently sampled from a multinomial distribution. For convenience, we drop the collective index (i)\begin{document}$(i)$\end{document}. Then, the conditional joint probability mass function of Fk+1,0,FFk+1,0\begin{document}$F_{k+1,0},F F_{k+1,0}$\end{document} cells is represented by(70)P(Fk+1,0,FFk+1,0|fk∗,hk∗)=N0!(N0−Fk+1,0−FFk+1,0)!Fk+1,0!FFk+1,0!×(1−fk∗−hk∗)N0−Fk+1,0−FFk+1,0(fk∗)Fk+1,0(hk∗)FFk+1,0,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle P(F_{k+1,0},F F_{k+1,0}|f_{k}^{*},h_{k}^{*})= & \, \frac{N_{0}!}{(N_{0}-F_{k+1,0}-FF_{k+1,0})!F_{k+1,0} !F F_{k+1,0}!}\times\\ & (1-f_{k}^{*}-h_{k}^{*})^{N_{0}-F_{k+1,0}-F F_{k+1,0}} (f_{k}^{*})^{F_{k+1,0}}(h_{k}^{*})^{F F_{k+1,0},}\end {aligned}$$\end{document}

where the number of S Sk+1,0\begin{document}$S_{k+1,0}$\end{document} is automatically set to be Sk+1,0=N0−Fk+1,0−FFk+1,0\begin{document}$S_{k+1,0}=N_{0}-F_{k+1,0}-FF_{k+1,0}$\end{document}. Then, the approximated multivariate normal distribution is N(N0pk∗,N0Mk+1)\begin{document}$\mathcal{N}(N_{0}\mathbf{p}_{k}^{*},N_{0}\mathbf{M}_{k+1})$\end{document} where the mean distribution is pk∗=(fk∗,hk∗)\begin{document}$\boldsymbol{p}_{k}^{*}=(f_{k}^{*},h_{k}^{*})$\end{document} and covariance matrix is Mk+1\begin{document}$\mathbf{M}_{k+1}$\end{document}. The diagonal terms of Mk+1\begin{document}$\mathbf{M}_{k+1}$\end{document} are variances σX2=X2¯−[X¯]2\begin{document}$\sigma_{X}^{2}=\overline{X^{2}}-[\overline{X}]^{2}$\end{document} and the off-diagonal terms are covariances σXY=XY¯−X¯Y¯\begin{document}$\sigma_{XY}=\overline{XY}-\overline{X}\;\overline{Y}$\end{document}. With cycle index k\begin{document}$k$\end{document}, we get the conditional probability of matured collectives Ppk+1,τ(p|pk∗)\begin{document}$P_{\mathbf{p}_{k+1,\tau}}(\mathbf{p}|\mathbf{p}_{k}^{*})$\end{document} by(88)Ppk+1,τ(p|pk∗)=∫01dζ∫01dηPpk+1,τ(p|ζ,η)Ppk+1,0(ζ,η|pk∗).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle P_{\mathbf{p}_{k+1,\tau}}(\mathbf{p}|\mathbf{p}_{k}^{*})=\int_{0}^{1}d\zeta\int_{0}^{1}d\eta P_{\mathbf{p}_{k+1,\tau}}(\mathbf{p}|\zeta,\eta)P_{\mathbf{p}_{k+1,0}}(\zeta,\eta|\mathbf{p}_{k}^{*}).$$\end{document}

We select the Adult collective among g\begin{document}$g$\end{document} Adult collectives such that the change in frequencies during maturation could be compensated. During maturation, a frequency distribution moves in different directions in (f,h)\begin{document}$(f,h)$\end{document} space depending on the initial composition (fk∗,hk∗)\begin{document}$(f_{k}^{*},h_{k}^{*})$\end{document} So, we take different directions to obtain the extreme value distributions. Considering only the sign of the frequency changes in f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} and h\begin{document}$h$\end{document}, we take either maximum or minimum. The mean change in h\begin{document}$h$\end{document} is always positive in the whole (f,h)\begin{document}$(f,h)$\end{document} space since dFF¯/dt\begin{document}$d\overline{FF}/dt$\end{document} is always positive in Equation 75. Thus, we choose the minimum value hk+1min\begin{document}$h_{k+1}^{\mathrm{min}}$\end{document} in every selection step.

If the mean fk+1,τ(i)¯=∫01df′∫01dh′ fPpk+1,τ(f′,h′|pk∗)\begin{document}$\overline{f_{k+1,\tau}^{(i)}}=\int_{0}^{1}df^{\prime}\int_{0}^{1}dh^{\prime}\ fP_{\mathbf{p}_{k+1,\tau}}(f^{\prime},h^{\prime}|\mathbf{p}_{k}^{*})$\end{document} is larger than fk∗\begin{document}$f_{k}^{*}$\end{document}, the minimum value among fk+1,τ(1),fk+1,τ(2),⋯,fk+1,τ(g)\begin{document}$f_{k+1,\tau}^{(1)},f_{k+1,\tau}^{(2)},\cdots,f_{k+1,\tau}^{(g)}$\end{document} will be chosen in the selection step to compensate for the frequency change in the maturation step.
